author: gradywardgoogle
comment:
Hey Cynthia,

Great work on this first pull request. I really appreciate that you've gone beyond the basic requirements, and added some cool functionality to your site!

Overall feedback: think about maintainability. Try to build your stylesheets and javascript in a way that won't need updating if you change the number of pictures you're displaying, or the order of elements on the page. Name variables a little more explicitly so that it will be easier to come back to this code and update it in the future.

I left a lot of feedback because we're here to learn, but this is a great start, and please ping me when you've resolved these comments and I'll take another look. Sorry to have toaken so long on this initial review!

Grady

author: gradywardgoogle
comment:
Here you're using getElementById for each element in a list. If you needed to add another profesh link, you'd need to add another line here.

A more resilient way of doing this would be to make a class "profesh" which you've already done, and use a for loop to iterate over all elements returned by document.getElementsByClassName. That way if you add or remove a profesh link, you won't have to add another line to your javascript!

author: gradywardgoogle
comment:
I see below that there's some logic to how you've decided to use whitespace. Here's a way to think about it:

1) whitespace should be used to separate semantically distinct blocks. Line 3 currently does that, but line 9 does not (the closing tag has the most relation to the block above.
2) whitespace should only be used to separate when it gives you concrete value. If you've got 2-5 distinct blocks separated by whitespace, that makes it clearer. If you've got a high ratio of whitespace to non-whitespace, that doesn't.
3) The most frequent cases of whitespace making sense are _between_ tags, very rarely would you want whitespace at the beginning or end of a tag

author: gradywardgoogle
comment:
I like how youve organized this block. I'd take another pass through this CSS and see if you can make it cleaner by:
1) grouping related properties (font.*, margin.*, top|left|bottom|right, etc)
2) Having a consistent ordering of properties between blocks (if you have position categories at the top in one, do it for all)
3) Using the same color format across the board (rgba is a great choice)
4) always have space between the colon and the property value
5) add semicolons to the end of every line, including the last one (this will make it easier to add properties in the future.

author: weiwong-g
comment:
I don't think you need to split the user comment into words. the doPost method is meant for accepting a comment from user (submitted from form). So in this doPost method, we should unpack the data and store the data in datastore.  After doing that you can simply redirect the user back to the main page, which by deafult should load you page with all comments.

So, you likely need a doGet method to handle getting the list of comments.

author: weiwong-g
comment:
Perhaps we should refactor this code into doGet()? So you use doGet() for frontend to fetch comments and use doPost() for saving new comments.

If you insist on using just doPost(), that will work too. But to avoid saving empty comments, you will have skip running datastore.put() if the commend is empty. I think doGet() + doPost() provide cleaner code though.

author: weiwong-g

I think it's worth adding a class comment to explain the purpose of this class. 

The name status is a little bit too generic.  Ideally, each class should have a clear purpose.

author: weiwong-g
comment: Not sure if I am reading this correctly.  You have response.sendRedirect("/index.html"); above, the probably there is no need to write the commends to the post response?  If you display comments in /index.html, the the redirect should be enough to display the new comment along with old comments there.

author: weiwong-g
comment: It seems like errors could be mistakenly reported as no files uploaded. Although I am not sure how errors are handled for uploads. So this comment is just meant to help you think about error handling.  In many cases it's tempting to use default (zero/empty) to assume no action. But we need to be careful to distinguish the cases where failure causes the default value to be returned. So it might be worth use a non-default value for zero/empty. Or we need to be explicit handling errors.

author: weiwong-g
comment:
If doPost() should only be called by requests from logged in users, then this is part of the API and should be clearly documented in the method comment section as Java doc.

The comment itself is not going to protect incorrect use of this method (Say, if frontend is developed by another person).  So it's will be a good idea to check and make sure a user is indeed logged in. If not, at least write a log entry. Or even provide some error message back to frontend.  (Perhaps you did check to make sure user is logged in last time my my comment may have caused you to change the code. Sorry for the confusion).

author: scottymb
comment: Similar comment here - in general, I almost never use `br`, and only do in a couple cases where it's definitely appropriate, like a mailing address. What you have here is a new paragraph, so instead of these, close your existing paragraph and start a new one. When you've done that, I recommend putting it on a new line of code, too, so it's nicer to read the file.

author: scottymb
comment: In general, I'd suggest removing a lot of the extra blank lines in here. Not all, but I try to use them when it helps make a clean logical grouping and when it helps visually break up a large chunk of text. And when using them, stick to one. That will make the final file feel tighter for people looking at it later.

author: scottymb
comment: In JavaScript, stick to 80 characters per line. This particular object will work nicely if you keep `const facts =` on the first line, then put each array member on its own line followed by commas and indented 2 spaces, then close the array on another line with no indent. Let me know if you have questions about that.

author: jcderry5
comment:
According to the guide, datastore stores its data as Entities, I cannot store them as Task objects. So the flow of data goes:
Take in data in the doPost() -> Convert into an Entity object -> Store entity in the datastore 
Then when I need the info:
Loop through each entity in datastore ->  Put each entity into a UserEntry object (previously named task object) -> Convert list of UserEntry objects to json -> print json for the JS file to read

author: jcderry5
comment: It's not really an exception that it would throw. It's just that whenever this if statement is false, I don't want it to add that empty entity to the datastore.

author: gradywardgoogle
comment: Josiah, great work. This code is exceptionally clear, well formatted, consistent and readable. I've rarely seen this level of attention to detail from interns, and I really appreciate how easy it makes my review process! Keep up the good work.

author: gradywardgoogle
comment:
Can we refactor this to get it to the point where we don't store state in the servlet? Ideally every reuqest we make to the servlet will be independent from any other request - and state in the servlet seems to counter-act that. 

I think this could just be a method variable in doGet, right? then you could pass it into getNumComments.

author: gradywardgoogle
comment: I definitely appreciate the error handling! But instead of using print statments, let's throw an exception (perhaps an IllegalArgumentException here). In general, we want to code _defensively_, which means we want to fail requests that are poorly formed, or don't conform to our expectations. Throwing an exception is a good way to indicate that to the calling user (whether that's Javscript that you write, or an accessor of your API).

author: gradywardgoogle
comment: Can you do that throughout? IllegalArgumentExceptions are a good semantic choice in many cases (where you're validating the input of a user), but so are IllegalStateExceptions (when you're validating an assumption you have about what a function or datastore will contain/return)

author: gradywardgoogle
comment: I think this probably shouldn't go in the for loop? We probably only need to set it once.

author: gradywardgoogle
comment: meganit: we'll want to use lower-dash-case for HTML classes and IDs. This isn't a huge deal, but it will be helpful as we build up a bigger code base.

comment: HTML tag attributes like `href` here are normally written without any spaces between the attribute name, equals sign, and attribute values. So, this should be `href="#home"` rather than `href ="#home"`.

comment: If this will be a unique element on the site, like I suspect it will, I suggest making it an ID rather than a class. Addressing IDs in CSS is easier and quicker for the browser to do, compared to looking for classes on all elements.

author: peap
comment: `#content` matches an element with an ID of `content`, but the div in your HTML that I think you are trying to address only has a class called `content`, so these rules aren't being applied; either the HTML or CSS should change.

author: peap
comment: My version of Chrome adds an 8pm margin for the `body` element when I view your page, so a width of `100vw` means that get the tiniest horizontal scroll bars. I'd experiment with different width units if you're experiencing the same thing. (I think your intent is to take up the full width of the user's browser, but no more.)

author: peap
comment:
Just a quick comment about commit messages. You can see how github (and other interfaces) display the first line of the commit message like an email subject line, so it's useful to make that first line of the message a good summary of what the commit does. (vs. your 859655a commit, which starts with a bulleted list and thus has an implied summary of "-change title to reflect user", which only partially describes the commit.

A better message for that commit messages would be something like:

> Make the requested changes from PR #1 
>
> The changes were:
> - thing one
> - thing two
> ...

So in general, you want a short summary, followed by a blank line, followed by more details about the commit, if warranted.

author: peap
comment:
This file and ServerStatsServlet.java both lost their end-of-file newlines in this PR. It's not a really meaningful change, and probably happened inadvertently when they got opened in some editor and possibly re-saved. That happens all the time.

However, we should avoid including changes in a commit that don't contribute to the purpose of the commit. Concretely, in cases like this, if I noticed an unexpected file in the list of files that git shows me when writing a commit comment, I would cancel the commit process, revert the unnecessary changes, and then start the commit process again. In fact, my usual workflow is usually to review a full diff of my workspace compared to the last commit before I initiate a commit, so that I can ensure I'm only committing what I intend.

It's not a huge difference in this case, so I'll leave it up to you whether you want to add back the newline to these files in a future commit in this branch.

author: peap
comment: It would be good to wrap this all up in a function, even if we just immediately invoke it from this file or in some place from the HTML. Most of the JavaScript you'll write will be in a function, which gives us more control over when it runs and makes it reusable. Right now, it runs ~sometime~ after the script is loaded by the browser... but it could happen any time, which isn't always what we want.

author: peap
comment: The `comment` variable appears to be a list of comments, but the name implies that it is one comment. Let's rename it in the plural to reflect the data it holds.

author: peap
comment: Take a look at JavaScript template literals to make this a little easier to read: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Template_literals. That will let you add the HTML in a single statement.

author: peap
comment:
JavaScript's `for...in` operator is kind of weird; it doesn't guarantee the order of iteration, so you might find that comments are displayed in an unusual or inconsistent order. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for...in

Instead, we can use `comment.forEach()` or `for (x of comment)` to iterate over this array.

Most of the JavaScript you'll write will be in a function, which gives us more control over when it runs and makes it reusable. author: peap
comment:
If `comments` is an Array, we should use [`for...of`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for...of) instead of [`for...in`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for...in). For one thing, `for...in` doesn't guarantee the order of items returned, so it may undo any ordering of comments you've prepared on the backend.

It will give you each element of the array as your loop variable (`x` currently, but we probably want a more descriptive name) and you can hand that off to `addComment`.

comment:
There is a lot of code repetition in this site which would be good to address. It creates code bloat and can lead to errors. For example, you have some references to blog.html labelled as Blog and some as Vlog.

Surprisingly, it looks like there is no way to deal with it in pure HTML (https://css-tricks.com/the-simplest-ways-to-handle-html-includes/). In the old days I would use iframes, but that's probably even worse than duplication.

I think it worth to discuss within the pod, or with your virtual support. If there is no easy solution we can submit as is.

author: rgcase
comment:
Nice, looks like you made it so that you'll cycle through all of them at least once before ever repeating. That's even better than my suggestion.

I think we can probably still make this a little simpler though. For one, you've got a bunch of code for setting the text on the `factContainer` mixed in with your logic for choosing a fact, so I think it would be nice if you could split them up. I suggest a helper function, something like `chooseRandomFact()` that just returns the chosen fact and then update the UI with that value.

Also it seems like your function takes in the `prev` argument but then also breaks out of its scope to refer to the `last` variable. You probably don't need both and I think it just makes your code harder to follow. You might even want to just use the actual value in the UI as your `last` variable.

I also think it might be even simpler and have less indirection if you just compare the `fact`s themselves for equality rather than doing all the bookkeeping with the indices. Integer comparison would be more efficient than String matching but I think we should focus on simplicity and readability here.

author: rgcase
comment: The `.delete(...)` method can also take a `List<Key>` which means it can delete them all in one query rather than a query per-key. It'll be more efficient if you can gather the `Key`s in a `List` and then delete them after.

author: rgcase
comment: I don't think we want to convert this HTML to JSON do we? We want to actually render the HTML directly. You probably don't need the `html` array and you can just call `out.println(...)` and pass in your HTML strings.

author: rgcase
comment: This is the same URL for both login and logout. Maybe extract it out to a `REDIRECT_URL` constant?

author: rgcase
comment:
This is a good use case to use `java.util.Optional` instead of returning `null`. `Optional` lets you represent a value that might not be there, similar to how null works but it's more explicit, so it signals to the caller (using the type system) that they should think about how to handle the empty case, whereas right now it's not obvious to the caller that this method might return `null` (even if it's in the javadoc).

Optional has methods like `.ifPresent(...)` that let you do something with the value inside, or you can explicitly check with `.isPresent()` and then call `.get()`.

You can create an `Optional` with `Optional.ofNullable(...)`.

author: rgcase
comment: Similarly here, you want to return HTML not JSON.

author: rgcase
comment: As I mentioned in another comment, you can write directly to `out.println(...)` here instead of gathering everything in a list first. You also probably don't need all these intermediate Strings, you can just pass them directly to `out.println(...)`.

author: shenqiuz
comment:
Hardcoding a number "17" to the code means that we need to update the number whenever we add/remove images in the folders. Two possible ways to improve it:
1) Put all images into a single folder and read the folder to determine the number of images in the folder. Also, you don't need to fix the prefix to "lagos-". You might be able to get the file name directly.
2) If the option 1 is too difficult, you can put a file close to the folder of images, and add the hardcode value there. Or you can extract the hardcode value to the top of this file. In this way, people don't need to scroll down the file to find the hardcode value when they need to modify it in the future.

author: mctavish
comment: I don't believe that the starter project has called this out yet, but at this point you're accepting untrusted user content, storing it in a database, and then injecting it into other users' DOM.  This is the exact recipe for an XSS attack (if you think you have time, play around with this a bit!).  No need to fix it right now, but be aware of it and be open for ways to address it as you continue through this project.

author: mctavish
comment:
jsdoc is similar to javadoc.  The styleguide wants it on virtually all code, but I think that a reasonable compromise is to put it on the more public aspects of the interface.

https://google.github.io/styleguide/jsguide.html#jsdoc

author: mctavish
comment: (seriously, do document the units for timestamps.  I can't count the number of bugs I've found and created related to this sort of oversight)

author: mctavish
comment:
Untrusted from a security perspective.  There are a few ways that accepting user content can be risky, and the risk is inflated when you surface one user's input to another user's browser.  For example, a potential attack path would be that a user leaves a comment that contains a script that installs a keylogger.  Each person that visits the page and views the comment would then have their browser compromised (within the scope of that website).

It looks like there's some scrubbing happening (probably through the gson serialization) that prevents some of the obvious injection which is good.

Again, no action needed here, but I just wanted to raise the idea that any time that you allow a user to either store data in your system or to show their content to another user, there are risks that are good to keep in mind.

author: mctavish
comment:
Looks pretty good as a first step.

The general rule for client/server interaction is to *never* trust the client.  In the case of auth, it's normally achieved by requiring the user to sign into the client, and then passing a token along with requests (such as adding a comment) which the server can then validate.  For AppEngine, I believe that the token bit is managed behind the scenes for you, so checking whether the UserService believes that the user is logged in before accepting mutating operations should suffice.

Feel free to reach out to me if you have questions about this!

author: chris-blay
comment: I generally prefer to end "single tag" tags like img and meta with /> instead of > to help visually indicate they are expected to not have a paired closing tag. AFAIK browsers don't care, so feel free to follow either convention. FWIW it looks like /> isn't used anywhere so that means nothing needs to be done unless you'd prefer to switch all instances out for />

author: chris-blay
comment:
Looks like you've already done the math, so may as well leave these as-is, but I wanted to let you know browsers will (unless instructed otherwise) preserve the aspect ratio of images so generally only one of height/width needs to be specified - the other value will be computed automatically

That said, specifying both together does allow the layout process to be accurate for an img element before the actual image is downloaded, so sometimes doing the extra work up front is worth it

This is all FYI - no action required

author: rharagutchi
comment:
General Java style: If you don't explicitly need comments to be ArrayList (e.g. need to pass it to a function that requires ArrayList), we usually just declare it as the more generic version, List

Also, depending on your version of java, you shouldn't have to declare <String> again in the constructor.

`List<String> comments = new ArrayList<>();`

The compiler assumes you want `new ArrayList<String>()` because you declared it to be a String List already

author: codewithjess
comment:
Hmm I would argue that this method could actually be renamed to `convertToJson`.
* `usingGson` describes the implementation details of the function, so it shouldn't be in the method name. This method shouldn't be tied down to using gson.
* this method can convert any list of strings into json, so `commentList` feels a little restrictive

Does this function need to take in an ArrayList? Prefer to make parameter types generic - in this case we can use List<String> instead.

This function can also be static since it doesn't use any members of the class.

author: Hiram-Silvey
comment: setProperty takes in a String propertyName and and Object value as parameters. This could be updated to store a JSONObject directly, instead. This would simplify the above for-loop translation code as well, as you'd only need to pull out the JSONObject and then insert that into the Array, rather than building a new JSONObject each time using individual fields.

author: yjennywang
comment:
Hmm, I'm very surprised by this.

< head > is usually reserved for metadata elements.

Some context:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/head
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26088555/placing-a-div-in-head

It could be browsers doing weird things and fixing up the html markup, even though it's standards compliant... though looking at this again, it looks like you have the same text on line 14. Are you sure it's not showing that instead?

author: yjennywang
comment:
Hmm! This is surprising to me, because < head> is reserved for metadata elements. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/head  and https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26088555/placing-a-div-in-head for some context.

It could be browsers trying to proactively fix the markup, but looking at this...you have a similar line on line 14.

Are you seeing two "Sean Tisdale Portfolio"? Or is it possible that only the one on line 14 is showing up?

author: yjennywang
comment:
Instead of using style, I'd suggest using the CSS style sheet.

In general, we want to keep the HTML as a semantic representation of the page. The stylesheet should handle all styling. It makes it easier to change things and keep things consistent when the styles are kept in one place. This also means that you can hotswap styles just by changing the CSS stylesheet you're using.

author: yjennywang
comment:
Can you add the fix onto this branch? Under usual cases, we don't want to abandon pull requests -- the review comments on this are part of the history of the change. :) And it'll take the reviewers longer to review, because they'll lose state on what has already been reviewed.

If there's a specific commit on that you just need to bring over, then you can get the commit id from that branch (after seeing `git log`) and then `git cherry-pick $commit_id` on this branch. We can walk over how to do that in person tomorrow, if you like; cherry-pick is useful to know but there are some subtleties and pitfalls.

Otherwise, you can just copy over the change from that branch, and make a new commit.

author: daniel-google
comment:
Headers should usually follow a hierarchy, i.e. sub-sections of `<h1>` are denoted by `<h2>` and so on.

If you're using `<h3>` here because you want a smaller font, that can be done by styling `h2` with CSS, e.g.

```css
h2 {
  font-size: 0.9em; /* play around with the actual value until it looks good to you */
}
```

author: daniel-google
comment:
Looks like this includes all of the files in your previous PR as well, you'll probably want to merge that PR first and rebase the slideshow changes so that the diff shows only what's new.

I believe the process for this would be:

1. Merge the previous PR to apply it to github's `master` branch
2. Pull that change down to your local repo with `git pull origin master`
3. Run `git checkout slideshow` to checkout your local slideshow branch (if you're not already on it)
4. Run `git rebase master` to re-apply the changes on top of the latest master
5. Run `git push origin slideshow` to update the PR

author: estep-google
comment:
This variable here isn't changing. That makes it `final` (meaning it will not/cannot be changed). There's another concept, `static` that can apply here - those are variables that are at the class level and there is only one copy of it no matter how many objects get instantiated.

To be a bit more proper:

`private static final String WELCOME_MESSAGE = "Welcome to my.....";`

This declaration goes right under the class declaration line. Note the variable name, it's java style for static finals.

author: estep-google
comment:
Change to: `response.getWriter().println(WELCOME_MESSAGE);`

The static variable can be called in any function in the class, just as if it was a local variable to the method. This also means you do not need your local `message` variable.

comment: `numComments < 0` is better practice. It will catch any negative input value (say I request -3?).

author: estep-google
comment: This section isn't necessary. Returning a negative value when you can't parse is fine, but if the user sends a negative value, there's no reason this method should check for that. It's up to the method that calls this to decide what to do with the value returned. Remember: helper method.

author: estep-google
comment:
I suspect the walkthrough told you to use -1, but I think it's better practice here to use `Integer.MIN_VALUE` instead (the most negative number that is still an integer). It frees up callers to accept a value of -1.

This is called a "helper method" (or sometimes a "private helper method"). You don't want to put too much logic in here and as much as possible leave the actual "decisions" to the callsites. In this case, right here in this method we don't care if the input value is -1 (it will parse correctly), but if it is and you also return -1 in the error state, a caller can't tell the difference.

daniel-google
comment:
this will actually throw a NullPointerException if the parameter is null -- since `isEmpty()` is called on the result of `getParameter()` before it is null-checked

also consider storing into a local to avoid redundant calls to `getParameter`, e.g.

```java
String value = request.getParameter(parameter);
return value == null || value.isEmpty() ? def : value;
```

(second line is using a [ternary operator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%3F:))

author: daniel-google
comment:
nit: same here, consider storing to a local

also I noticed handling for the empty string differs between `#getParameterOrDefault` and `#getPropertyOrDefault` -- one method isn't necessarily better than the other, but it's always good to be consistent

author: daniel-google
comment:
It's more flexible to use an Object here, as it allows you to easily add additional information later (e.g. logged-in email address).

It also makes the meaning of the response a bit more predictable, as you can use a keyed boolean instead of these special `in` and `out` strings:

`
{"isLoggedIn": true}
`

(though don't just return the JSON string directly, use an Object and have Gson convert it)

author: tambchop
comment:
It's probably not the most efficient solution, network traffic wise, to:
1) request that all comments be sent from the server to the browser, and..
2) send N individual deletion requests from the browser to the server.  (where N is the total number of comments)

That process results in N + 1 total requests, and it also involves the server sending the actual text content of all comments to the browser, which doesn't need it in this case.

There are a lot of potential ways to reduce the number of over-the-network service calls that need to be made:
- You could add another parameter to your delete-comment endpoint called something like "shouldDeleteAll" which is just a boolean, and if that is set, you ignore the "id" parameter and just delete all comments.  This way, you wouldn't need to fetch all comments in the first place.. so only one total call to the server =o
- You could change the "id" parameter to "ids" and let it be an array.. the con here is that you would still need to fetch all of the comments initially to get all of the ids.  But two total calls to the server isn't terrible.

There's another way.. possibly the most correct way, but it involves a deeper understanding of web API design, and I doubt that the tutorials mean for you to have to learn web practices to this depth, but I thought I'd share it as I only vaguely remembered it myself and think it's an interesting thing to know / could be useful later:
I think most web server APIs support a few more methods in addition to GET and POST.  The others are PUT (or PATCH) and DELETE.

The idea is that for something like comments, you would send a GET request to "/comments" when you want to retrieve one or more comments, you'd send a POST request to "/comments" when you want to create a new comment (like you're doing now), you'd send a PUT request to "/comments" when you want to update or edit a comment, and you'd send a DELETE request to "/comments" when you want to delete one or more comments.  It's kind of cool... notice how all of the requests are sent to the exact same URL path i.e. "/comments", but the method type dictates which action should be taken.

And Java servlets support this.  You can override the doDelete method to implement the DELETE action =o

Anyway, I want to emphasize that I'm not an expert on this stuff and that nothing I'm suggesting is definitively the "right" answer.  More than anything, I think the best thing to consider from what I've said is the very first part, which is that it would probably be best to save network traffic by not having to send N requests to the server when what you really want to do is telling it to delete "all" of the comments =)  However you would like to go about that is up to you!

Here's Google Cloud's official guidance on web API design, if you feel like reading more:
https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/standard_methods

author: tambchop
comment: Haha.. I left a giant comment about web API endpoint design philosophy which I *definitely* don't expect you to explore in depth.  The important part is really just the first few sentences, with the additional thoughts and theory (starting with my "There's another way.." comment being more of an optional read if you are interested in learning some more advanced stuff =)

author: UriBombastic
comment: I was thinking about how to implement that and I'm not sure if there is a good way. The reason I don't just store them in the first place is that every time the comments page is refreshed it needs to pull the entities from the datastore to be up-to-date with all the latest comments, including those from other users. A possible solution would be to aggregate new comments to a stored list of comments, but that entire list would have to be compared to the list of comments being pulled from the database, at which point the servlet may as well just return the data pulled from the database instead of needing to compare it with stored data first. Do you have any ideas on how I could efficiently store comments?

author: cisxingg
comment:
I think a cleaner way to do this would be:
1. Use results.asList and then use a for loop like:
for (int i = 0; i < numComments; i++) { [access the entity from the list] }
2. After prepare(query), use FetchOptions.Builder.withLimit to limit the number of query requests to numComments and that way you don't have to keep the extra counter around.

comment:
This is a constant.

In general, you should never omit var/const/let in your variable declarations.  Back in the day, Internet Explorer used to self-destruct when you omitted it (and lots of federal agencies and banks were stuck on IE6 for ages and ages).  I don't know if that's still true but better not to find out the hard way :)

comment:
Make body take up the entire space of the page, right now if you go outside the body you get a pointer with a circle behind it which is much less cool than you intended.

You can use the Developer Tools in Chrome to find the <body> tag in the Elements section, set the background-color attribute to blue, and play with the settings until it looks like you want.  That way you can see clearly how much space it is taking up (also test how it works when you resize the screen).

author: anbenson
comment:
Some notes/questions that didn't fit anywhere else:
- me.html is an empty file - was this committed intentionally?
- Generally the node_modules folder is not committed to git. Instead, the README has instructions for setup (including npm install package.json or whatnot). But I'll ignore it since this is just a project for the week. However, if you are only using a single file of bulma, maybe only commit that one?
- Can you clarify whether bulma is only for CSS, or if it's for some JS dependencies as well?
- I'm not sure I'm running your project correctly. If there are things I need to do, can you put them in the README? I'm running a HTTP server at portfolio/src/main/webapp/ and I see the website but JS doesn't seem to work - for example, clicking on the hamburger button does nothing, which makes it hard to review the header and links to social media, which this PR adds :)

comment:
You generally wouldn't want to hide this in JS - if there's a problem with the JS (it didn't load, user's browser disables or has an issue with your code, etc), then everything is shown. It also means there's a delay - it isn't hidden until the script runs.

Instead, the general recommendation is to set it to display:none initially in CSS.

author: anbenson
comment:
Not sure if this is intentional, but this means that every time a request is made to your server, more comments are added to your list. In other words, the endpoint is not a simple "fetch me the data on server", it's a "add more data, then fetch the updated data".

If you only want to add these once, I'd move these comments.add statements out of the method.

author: anbenson
comment:
You almost always want "of" instead of "in" e.g.

`for (let i of comments) {`

However this means that `i` will be the actual string comment, not an index. To get an index, you'll need to do the usual `for (let i = 0; i < comments.length; i++) {` formula.

author: anbenson
comment:
So the code here feels a bit strange - you have an Entity object, deconstruct it into its parts, then put it back together again to add to the ArrayList. Why not add it right away?

But stepping back for a second - the code on line 54 turns the Entity object (which you don't know the internals of, it being from a 3rd party library) into JSON instead of turning a format you have control over (such as the Comment class you presumably are using in your other PR). This makes it so that your JavaScript below is forced to examine internal properties of the object which could change if the Entity library decided to change, which is brittle.

In summary, I would advise against serializing the Entity object directly to JSON. You can use the Comment object now, or since the only thing your JS uses is the content property, you can just serialize an ArrayList<String> of the content properties.

Let me know if this is confusing.

author: anbenson
comment: These string names ("content", "timestamp") are a bit fragile since they're constants that are used in more than one place. Can you make them `private static final String` constants instead? This protects against typos and partial changes to the names.

author: anbenson
comment:
`Comment` should not be capitalized since it is a variable name.

I recommend against the Array.prototype.forEach pattern - it's inverted, so it's harder to read at first glance than a for-of loop (I know I keep bringing for-of loops up, but it was created to fix all the problems with forEach, for-in, and for (let i = 0; i < ...)), and it's harder to debug since it takes in a function as an argument so you can't step directly into it in the JS debugger.

author: nicorod-google
comment: May I ask what the 5 and 4 are referring to here? Generally we want to try to avoid "magic numbers" ("arbitrary numerical constant. In other words, a random number that "just works" or "looks right" without a grounded explanation") as much as possible unless they are absolutely necessary. It looks like your drop down to change the amount of visible comments is not doing anything at the moment, could that issue possibly be related here? If so, how could we take both pagination and the max number of comments a user wants to see at one time into consideration?

author: nicorod-google
comment: Am I right in assuming the intent here is to see if there are too few comments on the page such that further pagination on the next button would not result in any new comments? If so, does that need to be dependent on the magic number "5"?

author: nicorod-google
comment:
I just want to make sure I properly understand your intent here. Say we have 10 total comments. 
Would that  mean the intent is to have 3 total pages, the first two pages with 5 comments each and the last page with the "No comments to display" text?
Or is the intent for the "No comments to display" text to only appear when we have 0 total comments, such that in this same example if we have 10 comments it would only be 2 total pages and the next page button is disabled on the second page?

author: lxcyqx
comment: the 5 and 4 are used to calculate which comments to load onto the page. For example, if the currPage = 0 (we are on the first page of comments) then we would have for (int i = 0; i<=4;i++) and index into the arraylist of comments to pull up the correct comments to display. Similarly, if we are on currPage = 1 (second page of comments) then the for loop would be for (int i = 5; i<=9; i++). Should I store 5 and 4 as a constant instead? Also the drop down does limit the number of comments. So for example, if you limit to 5 comments, and then you click the next button, there wouldn't be any comments to show. I don't think the dropdown is very necessary in terms of user experience given that I have added pagination, but it was mentioned in the walkthrough so I left it in there

author: lxcyqx
comment: I think I had a different understanding on the functionality of the dropdown. I was thinking that it would limit the total number of comments. However, I have no changed it so that the dropdown acts as a way to set how many comments are displayed per page.

author: lxcyqx
comment: Yes that was the intent. I have now changed it so that it takes in a variable (storing the number of comments the user wants to display per page)

author: lxcyqx
comment:
It's the first scenario that you brought up. What I have now is that if there are 10 comments, then on the second page the next button would still be enabled so if you click next then it would bring you to a page saying "No comments to be displayed." This would not happen if there were 9 comments. In that case there would only be a total of 2 pages. 

To handle the case in which there are a total of, say, 10 comments and you are displaying 5 comments per page. That means when you are on the second page, the next button would still be enabled because the javascript does not know that we are currently on the last page. I check to see if something is the last page by checking if the current page has fewer than the max number of comments that is able to be displayed per page. The reason javascript does not know that it's on the last page is that in the Dataservlet I query the data and use limit and offset to get the necessary data and then store that in an arraylist of comments and then return the comments. Thus, the javascript does not know how many total comments there are because the java is only returning a limited number of comments. I considered perhaps just returning a list of all the comments, and then display the appropriate ones on the javascript side. However, that would mean lots of unnecessary Comment objects are being created and stored in the arraylist on the java side. I am not sure how to get the total number of comments while also making sure that I'm not creating and storing comment information that I won't really be using because it slows down the loading of each page.

UPDATE: I found a way to fix all of this. So now it should reflect the second case you mentioned. 10 comments should only have a total of 2 pages and the next button is disabled on the last page

comment: If you wanted to match an element with both class `image-thumbnails` and `img`, then your css needs to be `.image-thumbnails.img` (no space). Spaces in the css selector means it only matches on child elements.

author: askewc
comment:
Nice work John! Looks pretty good, but I have high-level comments: 

Generally speaking, I'm not sure you should store binary files in git. They will significantly slow down repo cloning. For now, it's fine, since you don't want any dependencies, and there's not yet a GCP project in which to store them, but I thought I should mention it. Also, you should probably compress these jpegs-- they're super large, and will be slow to download! You can use Photoshop or ImageMagick to do that.

Also I feel like there's a bit of boiler-plate repetition here, since you're using static html and not a web-app or templating framework. That may be an issue with the original assignment though-- can you link me to it?

3. Push whatever changes you make while merging as a new commit to WEBDEVELOPMENT, so that this pull request will have only the changes you've made on top of your first pull request.

author: obasishaw
comment:
Ditto to my comment on your second pull request (https://github.com/Praful22/StepsummerII/pull/2).

In the future, if you're making a new branch with an entirely separate change from what's on an existing pull request, you should branch from master, not from the branch of the other pull request.

Specifically, to start a totally new branch after you've committed all your changes in your current branch and you're waiting for approval for a pull request, run these two commands:
git checkout master
git checkout -b newbranchname

This will first reset you to master (if you have uncommitted changes, it will warn you to commit those first), then start a new branch directly from master.

comment: This feels more like it should be `id="polaroid"` instead of `class="polaroid"`.  If you were going to create many elements that needed the same styling, then class would make sense, but in this case it seems like you are only going to create one polaroid, so id is preferred.

author: joshmcadams
comment:
Just `#body1` is a little cleaner. When you are referencing an ID, there is no need to include the element type.

That being said, `body1` isn't a very descriptive name.

I think that we might be mixing up our CSS a little much, and it will only get more complex as we add more. Really you need a `style.css` that contains styles that are used across pages. For styles that apply to just one page, it is a little cleaner to break them out into their own file `aboutme.css` or, though it violates the "separation of concerns" in the style guide, just have page-specific css in the page itself. I guess to play it safe with the style guide, a separate file is better.

author: mkmg
comment:
Please place all styling in a CSS file (this called [separation of concerns](https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html#Separation_of_Concerns) in the style guide). Here and below.

The idea is that the html file should contain the structure and content, while the css file should contain the styling. With this set-up, it's possible to display the same content in many different ways, just by changing the css file. The following site is a great example: http://www.csszengarden.com/

author: tzsebe
comment:
Nice work! I've put a bunch of comments; most are easy to change up. There's one where I say don't worry about it for now, because it would take a while, and it's more for your own edification. :)

Keep up the good work!

author: tzsebe
comment: You should add this around the top of your style.css

author: tzsebe
comment:
I was looking up some info about when it's desirable to use style inline. I was expecting a "use it for such-and-such one-offs", but what I found was "just never do it":

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9832513/when-to-style-directly-in-the-html-instead-of-css

Consider adding all styling to the css.

author: tzsebe
comment:
When we see
used in these cases, it usually means there's a styling issue elsewhere (e.g. spacing in your sections not handling things nicely on their ownbetween sections). BR is generally not a semantic thing, so while it's not the end of the world to have them, it's good to think about what other problem you're band-aiding when using these.

author: tzsebe
comment:
It's hard to tell if this is a legit comment, since I can't see the completed look, but in general: You want to use semantic tags whenever possible. For example, since your portfolio consists of a bunch of sections, you should likely use the <section> tag (which is really just a div that more expressively tells the reader what it is, and really helps with things like braille readers).

Have a look at: https://www.w3schools.com/html/html5_semantic_elements.asp

author: tzsebe
comment:
There's a good thing here, as well as something you can improve.

The good thing: Thank you for not using a table for layout. :)

Thing to improve: Many old CSS layout libraries (e.g. Bootstrap) use copious amounts of nested divs.

This is NOT something you need to change right now. But it's something you should look into for your capstone later:

Look into 'display: grid'

This allows you to specify up front how your layout should look, and then you can focus on just writing the actual content divs, rather than having to mess with nested row/column divs. So if you write CSS that changes the layout based on device width, your html doesn't need to be aware of that.

There's even a way to visually represent it in your CSS (see grid-template-areas). Your html will thank you for it, and it will free you to build nice responsive HTML without needing to address the layout as part of your HTML structure.

author: tzsebe
comment: Again - I am NOT asking you to make this change before you push; just be aware of it to make life easier for the capstone.

author: tzsebe
comment: Typo ("<<div")

author: tzsebe
comment: Consider being more defensive here. A bad post num would cause a failure.

author: tzsebe
comment:
For this kind of thing, you should separate logic from data. No need for anything fancy, but I'd say, split your pre-populated blog posts into an array of objects, and then loop over the array and run the code below.

Also, you might want to wrap this logic into a function, and have that function be invoked once the document fully loads (is it an onload event or somesuch?) This is so that you guarantee that when this Javascript runs, the document elements are fully created, so you don't get any weird failures caused by race conditions.

author: tzsebe
comment:
Should we be deleting the element here? Like, doesn't setting the innerHTML just make the element empty, without deleting it (meaning you now have an empty post in your list of posts), rather than actually deleting it?

I might be wrong about how this works - you can check it with your browser's 'inspect' functionlity.

Basically, if you have:

```
<section id="blog-posts">
  <article id="blog-post-1">
    blah blah blah
  </article>
  <article id="blog-post-2">
    blah blah blah
  </article>
  <article id="blog-post-3">
    blah blah blah
  </article>
</section>
```

And I do `document.getElementById('blog-post-2').innerHTML = ''`

Will I end up with:

```
<section id="blog-posts">
  <article id="blog-post-1">
    blah blah blah
  </article>
  <article id="blog-post-2">
  </article>
  <article id="blog-post-3">
    blah blah blah
  </article>
</section>
```
(where blog-post-2 isn't properly deleted)

author: tzsebe
comment:
nit: newline at end of file is desirable. :)

This is because if you run `cat <filename>` in linux, you want it to include the new line at the end of the last line so your command prompt shows up on a line of its own.

author: tzsebe
comment:
So, it looks like you're creating a toggle to allow showing and hiding posts.

Rather than creating and destroying the HTML elements (expensive), why not just make them visible/invisible, using the right css attribute? (possibly visibility, but you'll need to google for the right name).

As I mentioned above, you should have your posts sitting in a container (e.g. `<article id="blog-post-1">...</article>`), and then you should just have a two-liner that might look like:

```
blogPost = document.getElementById(<your post id>);
blogPost.setAttribute('visibility', 'no');
```

(note: I am totally making up the methods above, just typing that out to show you what I mean).

author: tzsebe
comment:
Oh my goodness! I just learned something about JavaScript: There doesn't seem to be a proper date formatting utility! This is kind of a shock. Most languages offer a basic thing that effectively gives you access to `strftime` (standard system call to format time), but at least according to [this site](https://css-tricks.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-date-in-javascript/#formatting-a-date), there isn't such a utility.

If it were me, I'd either go with one of the pre-determined ones (e.g. `toLocaleString`) or do something similar to what you're doing here. I believe the format you're using happens to exactly match `toLocaleString` so you'd be better off using that, rather than re-inventing the wheel here.

If you did want to customize your time formatting, my main advice would be to take the code to do that and move it into its own function, so that all parts of the page can benefit from it (e.g. if you have a blog post with some comments, the timestamp on the blog post and the timestamps on the comments could use the same formatting).

... but again, in your case, I'd just keep it simple and go with `toLocaleString`.

Also, if you want to better understand why Javascript's lack of support is so shocking to me, you should really watch [this short Tom Scott video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-5wpm-gesOY).

author: tzsebe
comment:
Nice job on taking the initiative to add pagination! And apologies in advance for the super-long feedback comment here.

If I'm reading your code right, what you're basically doing is:
* Always returning ALL comments on the backend
* Loading ALL comments on the frontend, and displaying only a portion, based on state variables you maintain

As you can imagine, the more comments you have, the slower the page will be.

One very quick fix is to only load the comments once, and then have the pagination buttons just use the data you've already loaded... then you can provide a refresh button (and refresh any time a comment is added), and you're set!

... that kind of thing would be sufficient if you knew you'd only ever get like 100 comments total, and limited it to 100 on the backend side. If what I'm about to describe below is not doable, or too much work, then just set a max number of comments to load and try not to reload it with every click on the page.

.... Now... Imagine you have millions, or hundreds of millions of comments. Popular youtube videos, as an example, have high hundreds of thousands to millions of comments. So, it goes without saying that loading all of them would be intractable.

## A General Explanation (actual thing you can/should do linked below):

The more standard way that pagination is solved is by making the backend API support pagination. A request into a backend API that supports pagination might look like:

```
REQUEST:
{
    // ... all the fields needed for the request, like if it's comments
    // on a post, there'd be a postId. This is not relevant here...

    // Pagination-specific stuff.
    pageSize: 50,
    pageToken: <discussed below>
}
```

The response would look like what's below. It's basically what you have now (a list of comments), but wrapped into a response object that includes some pagination specifics.

```
RESPONSE:
{
    // What you already have.
    comments: [ <comment1>, <comment2>, ...]

    // Pagination stuff.
    nextPageToken: "abcd1234...whatever"
}
```

When you first call the API when your page loads, you would just pass it a page size, and leave `pageToken` blank. Then, when it's time to load the next page, you would call the API again, except this time, you would pass in the `nextPageToken` as a `pageToken`, so it knows where to start. If there is no `nextPageToken` returned, you know there's no more pages.

In the backend, you need to make it so it doesn't load every comment. In the backend, you would need it to load only the tokens that belong on the next page.

For this to work, your data store needs to support indexing (say by timestamp). So, let's say your `pageToken` is "timestamp + comment ID". Then, you could query for comments greater than or equal the timestamp, and start "counting" only when you found the comment ID in question.

Then, you'd load up one more comment than your page size (so pageSize = 50 means you load up 51 total), but instead of returning that 51st comment, you convert it into a nextPageToken (grab its timestamp and ID and send it as the next page token). Then, when the user clicks, the next request will know where to begin.

There are a bunch of nuances I'm glazing over, like what happens when comments are deleted or things change. This is too complex to address in an overly-long code review comment already. :-)

The downside of this approach is that implementing "prev" is quite difficult... though the good news is, when dealing with unbounded things like comments, you don't usually need it, and you end up with something like facebook or youtube, where you just keep loading more. There ARE ways to do "prev" with this approach, but they're a bit more painful.

## What AppEngine datastore recommends you do

Turns out AppEngine's DataStore you're using has this functionality built in already:

https://cloud.google.com/datastore/docs/concepts/queries#cursors_limits_and_offsets

This includes some example code for achieving the result. It looks like it makes you return its internal cursor directly to the frontend, which has its own intricacies, but I believe you should be able to make this work with relative ease.

I decided that, when a comment is added or deleted, the behavior will be to reload the comments on the page back at the beginning. The cursorList is cleared and the page is set back to the default so that the list can be built again with the new order of comments. 
I originally was trying to let you stay on the same page, but it was confusing as to how to update the cursorList, so comments were appearing on multiple pages after deleting one or were getting skipped over after adding one.

author: tzsebe
comment:
Always try to separate "display logic" from "backend logic".

This servlet should not be returning HTML code. It should be returning a response (maybe even just a boolean), which your frontend code would interpret, and then generate html.

You really don't want backend code to couple this tightly with frontend html. Think of these servlets as if they were APIs. Pretend that, even though you're building a web app, someone else is writing a command line tool that's also talking to this servlet.

comment: Agreed - I would further encourage the name to reflect exactly what behavior is expected - so maybe rather than "success" something like "returnsHardcodedMessages" or "setsDefaultResponseValues", or something like that. author: NathanBricault
comment:
Neither way is strictly wrong/right. In this version you would end up with:
`getParameter(request, /* fieldName= */ potato).orElse("watermelon");`, which I think reads pretty clearly. I also generally like exposing the Optional in case you want to do more complicated manipulations with it in the future. 

Maybe the better question though is why you even want to allow default values. Do you want to support comments without a name? Or a comment body? I could maybe see an argument for anonymous comments, but not sure what use empty ones are.

In Google's[ sample code](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/java-docs-samples/blob/2e5996c68440134a79f1511c57529fa5cf987628/appengine-java8/datastore/src/test/java/com/example/appengine/QueriesTest.java) they initialized it only once and reused it for unit tests, so I will move the call outside of the doPost.

author: NathanBricault
comment:
A few thoughts on this: 
1) You don't necessarily have to go this route, but the best way I am familiar with of handling value classes in java is with Autovalue (https://github.com/google/auto/tree/master/value). This basically takes care of the gritty work of dealing with equals and hashcode in a sensible way, and generating setters/getters. 
2) If you do want to stick with the hand-rolled approach, I would lean towards have the value class itself be something like UserComment which stores the name and test, and then has a toEntity method for when you actually want the entity.

author: elefeint
comment:
Your unstash went all right, except git could not automatically figure out which was intended: nothing or the block of CSS, so it surfaced the conflict. It seems pretty likely that the block of CSS is what you were going for, so just delete lines 10, 11 and 90, and you'll be all set.

The only thing is that the unstash brought back the `tag{` pattern -- insert spaces, so it ends up looking like `tag {`.

author: elefeint
comment: JSON conversion looks good! A few minor comments and a question about whether you want to have messages, quotes or both.

author: elefeint
comment: Consider using a more verbose variable name, like `messages`. Typically in Java, single-letter messages are used in only boilerplate scenarios such as loop index variables.

author: elefeint

Good use of a helper method to move the hardcoded message population away from the main `doGet()` logic!

author: elefeint
comment: Consider renaming from `message` to something like `jsonString` or `messageJsonString` (because `message` is used in a lot of places to mean a single message).

author: elefeint
comment:
I don't think you need the `quote` variable anymore, since this method now operates on messages derived from `message()` instead.
Similarly -- will you still be using the top-level `quotes` field and its initialization in `init()` for future functionality?

author: elefeint
comment:
Actionable: `getMessage` needs method parentheses -- `getMessage()`.

Less actionable, more handwavy comment:
Right now, `getMessage()` and `getQuote()` are doing largely the same thing (the only difference is text vs json). If you want to have both, messages and quotes under different buttons, consider splitting your `DataServlet` controller into two controllers -- `MessageDataServlet` and `QuoteDataServlet`.

```
private final ArrayList<String> comments = new ArrayList<>();
```
Java8 can infer the type

author: EatingW
comment:
Here you are sending a request to the server to store this marker, and also creating a marker in the client for displaying it. It might cause the website to get out of sync if for example the marker wasn't successfully stored in the server. 

The server should always be the source of truth. After you send a marker to store in the server, you should also fetch the markers again from the server (for example, a call to fetchMarkers). This way you make sure that the markers displayed on your page are actually always the ones stored on the server. 

The "Note" here talks about the similar idea when deleting comments.  https://github.com/googleinterns/step/blob/master/walkthroughs/week-3-server/step-6-additional-features-walkthrough.md#deleting-comments-1

author: HidyHan
comment:
Consider using FetchOptions [1] to be more efficient. Suppose you have 10k comments and only wish to display 5. Retrieving all of them is wasteful.
[1] https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/java/javadoc/com/google/appengine/api/datastore/FetchOptions

author: HidyHan
comment: Suppose timestamp matters to you - you should retrieve it the first thing when you get a chance. Doesn't really matter here since there are only two lines of statements ahead, but will matter if you wait until 1 or 2 RPC calls before retrieving the timestamp.

author: HidyHan
comment:
Correcting myself: per page 132 of [1] Iterables only retrieve a small batch of entries as needed as you advance, so efficiency won't be too much of a problem. But using FetchOptions can still improve some readability :)

[1] http://netoearth.com/book/ProgrammingGoogleAppEngine.pdf

author: HidyHan
comment:
Style nit: prefer
`if (cond) { continue; } doTheRest();`
over
`if (!cond) ( doTheRest(); )`
Chances are doTheRest will have more nested calls and there will be too many layers if it already started within a if block.

author: HidyHan
comment:
Style nit: don't need to name the two variables and can just do assertEquals(actual, expected_expression). The rationale is then reader needs to go back to check "what is expected again?".

Also note the order swap. assertEquals(var, 3) is easier to read than assertEquals(3, var) as it fits the natural language better.

author: hajiler
comment: I intended to create separate pull requests, 1 for finishing the written details of the page, and the other for adding an image folder containing a profile picture. But I added them both to same the branch and can't separate them now. So my question is should I be creating separate branches for each commit pull-request?

author: jessrenteria
comment:
> I intended to create separate pull requests, 1 for finishing the written details of the page, and the other for adding an image folder containing a profile picture. But I added them both to same the branch and can't separate them now. So my question is should I be creating separate branches for each commit pull-request?

In general, I tend to prefer smaller, isolated changes. Here's a discussion on the benefits of doing so: https://google.github.io/eng-practices/review/developer/small-cls.html

Our internal code review tool has some pretty good support for doing this with separate branches that depend on each other, but it looks like git / GitHub [doesn't](https://stackoverflow.com/q/26619478). This is probably something we'll have to spend a bit of time to figure out. For now feel free to just add dependent commits to the same branch, and just keep the individual commits tiny, as that will still let us keep our code reviews focused.

If you have some totally independent commits, go ahead and make a new branch so you have can a separate PR.

author: jessrenteria
comment:
Nit: s/biking,dancing/biking, dancing/

Note: if you ever see us put "nit" in a code review, all it means is that we're nitpicking something not that important (like a small typo). Usually it's just the difference between correctness and polish. Putting another pair of eyes on a PR will almost always surface something like this, even on mine or Ali's :)

author: ahorjia
comment: Try to use "interfaces" when defining member variables. In this case it is better to use a "List" instead of "ArrayList". List is an interface and ArrayList is a concrete class. In Object Oriented Programming it is better to hide "implementation details" as much as possible and in this case ArrayList is an implementation detail

author: jessrenteria
comment:
`timestamp` is an ambiguous variable / property name for a long.

Right now a reader away from this definition will only know that it's a long representing a time and nothing else. If could very well be seconds, microseconds, nanoseconds, etc.

Consider changing to something like `timeMillis` or `submissionTimeMillis`.

P.S. if you already have comments in Datastore with the other property name you may need to wipe them.

author: peizhaoou
comment:
Is there a particular reason to put this class as a nested class of DataServlet? Unless with a good reason, I think we usually have a separate file for new classes.

Also, it may be good to reconsider using "Message" as the class name. Such names are usually very overloaded and used by many low-level framework code as well. Try to be more concrete. For example, if it's about comments, using CommentMessage would be better. But it's your call for other options.

author: peizhaoou
comment: For new class (which is a new type), it would usually be good to put sufficient comments in the class definition to describe what it is for. Things can become more complex over time and more context would be important to readers and collaborators.

author: peizhaoou
comment:
In Java, everything is a reference. For example, "value" variable here is a reference to a String object, and Java provides two types of equality comparison:
(1) checking if the reference is null, meaning whether the reference is pointing to any object. Your "value == null" is doing this;
(2) checking if the object referenced by a variable is indeed equal to the content of a given object, where you would use something like "value.equals("")", which says if the object referenced by variable "value" actually equals to the empty String object.

In this case, I think you should use the second one since the caller always passes "" to defaultValue, meaning that it always points to some object (i.e., value is never null here).

author: jessicaslaughter
comment:
It looks like GitHub defaults to showing 125 characters in a line in its diff view, so I'd suggest breaking this line off at 125 characters and putting the rest of the sentence on a new line. This makes it easier and nicer to read and is a good habit to get into (at Google, all lines are broken off at 100 characters).

There might be a way to set up a rule in your IDE so it shows a line at the 125 character mark while you're coding (like this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29968499/vertical-rulers-in-visual-studio-code).

author: jessicaslaughter
comment: You should lean on the paragraph element containing this text to dictate when a line gets broken off instead of manually breaking it off into multiple lines. So in this case, your sentences should fill the whole line up to the 125 character limit and then you can break off to a new line. Since this PR is just about adding body text, you can add any styling in a separate PR (don't worry about doing that here).

author: geekster777
comment:
It's a pretty common best practice to require a newline to be the last character in a file. This helps keep the `git blame` cleaner so that devs only modify lines they actually changed. So they wouldn't be changing line 46 to add content after it. It's the same reason folks will require commonly modified arrays to have each element on its own line with a trailing comma (even the last one):
```
const vals = [
  1,
  2,
  3,
];
```
```

This new line can be removed since it's not really adding to the readability of the file (same with other extra lines in this file). Generally, new lines between elements are used to improve the readability of the file by grouping larger, logical chunks of the template together (like if you had a large section sharing about your cooking experiences).

You might need to modify some settings in your IDE that could be adding these lines in automatically!

Since img is a void element (it can't have child elements), you don't need to close it using the / and can just remove that character. Same with the other img tags in this file.

More info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23890716/why-is-the-img-tag-not-closed-in-html
Also a style guide reference you can look to: https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html#Document_Type

comment:
Best practice for a multiline html tag is to have one attribute on the first line and horizontally align the others to it:
```
<foo bar="baz"
     zoop="doop"
     hello="world">
```

comment: Consider using classes instead of id's. Browsers assert that there's only one instance of each id on a page, which makes them very fast to query for but easy to misuse. Especially for generic container-like elements, it's preferred to use classes.

author: geekster777
comment: Any reason you're using `rem`'s? It'll be helpful to scale with the root font size if you expect it to be variable, although you may find it easier to scale things with `px` since that will remain constant between projects. Not required, but a suggestion since I noticed your later PR's use `rem`'s exclusively.

author: laptou
comment: I'm in the habit of using `rem`s as much as possible just because it makes it easier to scale things for accessibility / tweaking the UI / responsiveness. I always set the root font size to 16px anyway, so I don't really think consistency will be an issue, but thanks for the tip.

author: geekster777
comment: Yeah, this one's up to you. It's best practice to not use _general_ id names (like "content", "nav", or "footer") since there are potentially multiple of these that could be added to the page in the future. Normally reserving them for id's like "cheesecake-recipe" since there's not a likely namespace collision. Again, it's fine here, but something to keep in mind when collaborating on larger projects.

const foo = () => document.createElement('div');

const foo = () => document.createElement('div');

author: laptou
comment:
Using an IIFE when it is not necessary seems like an equally bad, if not worse, solution than adding ESLint disable comments to me. It is significantly more verbose and will puzzle someone reading this code in the future. I could put a comment next to it that says "this is to get rid of the ESLint error", but then why can't I just use a comment to get rid of the ESLint error?

Finally, using callbacks to handle the Promise will lead to control flow becoming more complicated when I add more stuff to this event handler (for example, showing a toast notification, which I also plan to implement using Promises).

I think that adding ESLint disable comments is fine as long as I have gone out of my way to address all of the pitfalls that ESLint is trying to warn me about: in this case, floating promises are bad because weird things will happen if an error escapes from this promise. However, I have wrapped all functions that might throw errors in `try`/`catch`, so it feels safe to disable the lint.

What do you think?

author: laptou
comment:
`getParameter` did not work, because the form data is being sent as multipart form data and not URL-encoded form data. This is what happens when you send a `FormData` object using `fetch()`. 

I could work around that on the client side, but this seemed like a more robust solution because it also makes it easy for me to do server-side validation (in a future PR I take advantage of this by truncating comment text at 50000 bytes, which I could not do if I was not handling the bytes directly. If I did not do this, it would make it pretty trivial for someone to DDoS my app).

author: devonwasson
comment:
okay, here comes a somewhat lengthy comment. 

I understand what you're going for here with initializing these variable. if you initialize them once, you don't have to do "var" before the variable name when you go to overwrite them below. Additionally, they'll technically exist so, if somehow a user manages to pass an ID that doesn't match any of the IDs you're accounting for in your if/else cases, the lists will exist and things won't crash. 

_However_, things will fall apart when page_heading[0] and page_heading[1] are called. Let's say that my clickedId was "devon" which is not one of the ones you test for. in that case, page_heading will just be an empty list. So calling page_heading[0] will result in an error (because there is nothing inside the list). 

There are a few ways around this. The first is to check that page_heading[0] exists before calling page_heading[0] (so something like if (page_heading.length > 1 { do page_heading[0] and page_heading[1]}) but that might be more complicated than it needs to be. The second option is to avoid using lists at all. Lists are great for when we have an unknown quantity of things or if we want to iterate over a bunch of things. Considering we are always adding a constant number of strings to these lists and never iterating over them, we would be better off just having separate variables for the two strings in each list. For example, here, we can do:

var page_heading = "";
var page_heading_desc = "";

and then just change those four variables explicitly. This way, we are being more descriptive with our naming AND we get the benefit of not crashing if we never change those values (because they're already set to empty strings). 

img_ids_desc is a little more tricky because you DO end up iterating over it, but considering it is a list of lists, the sub lists have the same problem as above. That being said, the way to fix this is to use some sort of named container (object, hash map, struct (i dont think js has structs though... maybe it does) to hold those items in the sub list and then put those named containers in a list and iterate that way, but that's complicated and out of scope here so I would say img_ids_desc is fine as is, especially because you won't crash if nothing is added to it.

comment:
Instead of writing this long if-else chain within the function `expandDesign`, I recommend passing `page_heading` and `img_ids_desc` to `expandDesign` as parameters. That will help separate logic from data and make the code easier to read and maintain.

I also recommend writing distinct `expandEasDesign`, `expandFakeBandDesign`, etc, functions, each of which calls `expandDesign` with different parameters, instead of having one big function that takes the `clickedId` parameter.

author: devonwasson
comment:
If i understand your goal here correctly, you want to fetch the limit sent by the request and, if there is a valid option, use that value to get results. otherwise, default to 10. there are a few things we could change here that would make for better code:

- the way this is right now, you'll sometimes make two calls to results.asList. We can ensure we only ever make one call by rearranging things. If we get rid of the first assignment for limitedResults and move it to an else case below the if, we'll only ever make the call once. However, we're now rewriting essentially the same line twice, just with a different param. So what if, instead, we changed the logic that happens in our if/else to change the value of numQueries? Something like if (numQueries == -1) {numQueries = 10;} and then call results.asList afterwards with the numQueries param.

- the default value of 10 is not clear. This is what we call a "magic number" because we don't document this anywhere. It's often a good idea to name constants. that is, we can introduce a variable like "default_limit", assign it to 10, and then use that variable in the code rather than directly using the number 10

- Defaulting to 10 is fine but the way we do it could use some work. If we have a value of -1, we want to change that value to 10. but why -1? the getLimit function is lacking documentation that says we return -1 on error so someone calling the function would have no idea that's an option without reading code. So we can do one of a few things. We can add documentation and call it a day.  We can not return -1 and let the caller handle negative values. Or, we can throw an error when we get an unexpected value (and document that we throw this error). That way, if a value is truly incorrect, we force the caller to handle getting bad numbers. This prevents the caller from making mistakes as errors need to be handled or else the program will crash. So if this function throws an error (like IllegalArgumentException) and the caller needs to catch that error if it happens and handle accordingly (like using a default value).

author: devonwasson
comment: we should have an extra new line in between function definitions, just for added clarity.

author: devonwasson
comment: we tell our users that there is a max value of 10, but what if someone manages to pass in a number greater than 10? what if they passed in 999999999999? This might cause huge issues with your database and your server in returning this much information. We should do some server side validation to ensure that the max number is maintained.

comment:
Use a consistent style for choosing between whether to use an "id" or a "class".

Typically, id is used when the element is unique, and class is used when there will be several elements reusing that class.

In practice at google, we virtually never use "id" and only use "class".

author: jessrenteria
comment:
With Java, it's best practice to make instance fields like this private.

There are four different [access level modifiers](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/javaOO/accesscontrol.html) for instance members:

1. `public`
2. `private`
3. `protected`
4. package-private

If you don't specify one of the first three, the instance member becomes package-private, which means that other classes in the same package (`com.google.sps.servlets` as defined at the top of the file) can access the member.

In general, it's safest to keep the raw field completely private and expose methods which other classes can interact with which modify the field. That way, any invariants / assumptions you have about the field are maintained by the class containing it.
