author: dibenede
comment:
> A question about the commit messages: are you saying that each commit should contain the change I made for that commit in the first line and then bullet points for all the previous commit messages I made? So like for my most raecent commit about adding a project section, it would be:
> Finished the project section
> 
> * changed design and formatting
> * add a summary about me
> * add basic formatting
> * make information about hobbies available on click

No, sorry. I may have put my comment in a weird spot. Basically your first line should be a summary. If you have a small commit, the summary may be sufficient to describe what you did and you can call it good.

If you have a large commit, then it's a good idea to list out what's included in it. Sorry for the confusion.

author: dibenede
comment:
I recommend keeping the commit message as descriptive as possible. Git typically uses the first 80 characters before a newline as the brief message that will show up in the short commit log. You can then expand on it for the extended history view. So, for this change, I would do something like:

Add and format data about me (I think that's less than 80)

* Add a summary about me.
* Make information about my hobbies available on click.
* Add basic formatting.

author: dibenede
comment:
I don't know what the guidance was for the assignment, but some food for thought for when you get to the capstone:

I am always highly suspicious of building HTML/SQL/etc in strings. It tends to be quite fragile and difficult to determine if you actually got it right. One potential option is to move the template of what you want into a separate data file. Then you read it in at runtime (and probably cache it), and do whatever value filling you need then.

Another strategy is to embed the template in your code as a string variable somewhere. That way, the whole template is in 1 variable together, and you still do interpolation of your values later.

author: kmh287
comment:
A few possibilities:

- You could shuffle the array and then return each element one-by-one
- You could keep track of the last generated random number and regenerate if you get the same thing. (non-zero chance of stalling forever though) 
- You could keep track of the last generated random number and always return the next element if you regenerate the same number, or return the first element if the previously generated number is the last index in the array.

author: kmh287
comment: Unlikely loosely typed languages like python and JavaScript, Java requires that methods only return a single type. Since the return type is `String`, -1 can't be used. I'd recommend null to signal to a caller that the comment wasn't able to be retrieved from the request.

author: kmh287
comment:
I'd recommend calling this outside of this class and adding the translated text as an additional constructor parameter to this class. Part of software design is separating your application into layers. This Word class would be part of the model layer: it represents a Word in the flashcard application with the word in english, the destination language code, and the translated text. The model should be separated from the application's business logic i.e. how it interacts with the models. 

I would consider the translation to be part of the application's business logic and so I'd recommend pulling it out to the caller. So you could would 

```
String translatedWord = translate.transate(....)
Word word = new Word("Hello", "ru", translatedWord)
```

author: dibenede
comment:
You should try to avoid manually building HTML with strings as much as possible. It tends to be quite fragile and difficult to make sure it's correct over time. 

Some better options are to specify a template of the HTML in a file or even a single variable. Then you just fill the values later when you're ready to actually use it. Check out Angela's repo; I got her to follow this approach using java's Resource API.

author: mecolmg
comment:
Consider giving class names or ids to these elements rather than using the HTML tag name in your code, with an exception for the "base styles" of your page (i.e. use a particular font by default, remove underlines for all links, etc.). 

Class names or ids that are short and descriptive act as self-documentation for code, and are more performant to use as accessors than relying on child accessors. For the selectors you have below consider something like:
- `nav` --> `#nav`
- `nav ul` --> `.navLinks`
- `nav ul li` --> `.navLinkContainer`
- `nav ul li a` --> `.navLink`
- etc.

author: mecolmg

author: mecolmg
comment:
Be careful with using `vw`. It can really backfire if for example you had an ultra-wide monitor in which case this top padding would be way too big. 

It's more preferable to have media breakpoints like you've defined below for different device sizes. You could then easily define this padding should be 16px on desktop, 8px on tablet, and 4px on mobile or something like that.

author: mecolmg
comment: Woah... This is some crazy math for a font. Consider just using media breakpoints for the same reasons listed above on `vw`.

author: mecolmg
comment:
It's almost never preferable to return null for a function. If anything, you can use [`Optional`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Optional.html). 

In this case, it's probably preferable to throw an exception, because this shouldn't happen and if it does we don't want to make things more confusing for a client calling this servlet to debug and would rather give them a nice, short-but-helpful error message they can act upon.

I'd also recommend checking that the key is present using `blobs.containsKey("image")` **before** calling `blobs.get`, because you're assigning it to a variable which isn't marked as `@Nullable` but could be null. By checking with `containsKey` first, you're verifying that `blobKeys` is in fact of type `List<BlobKey>`.

author: mecolmg
comment: So you'd have two different error messages here. One for if there wasn't an image, and another for if the blobKeys is empty.

author: mecolmg
comment: Another case where we should throw a descriptive error.

author: brucezheng
comment:
Sorry I actually didn't see that you had responded to my comment about this previously. The reason I don't like this line is that it's not very readable and it's also very sensitive to DOM changes with your comment layout. Here are some possible solutions

1. Add ```commentText``` as a parameter of this function, so you have access to it without having to navigate the DOM tree.
2. Add the card DIV as a parameter when creating this function, so you can use ```querySelector```.
3. Add an arbitrary ID to each card div, like ```comment1```, ```comment2```, etc, when creating the comments, so you can use ```querySelector```.

You actually have the same issue with finding score, but it's less serious.

author: Alfredhgoog
comment:
Website looks great.

Just one minor comment about naming. Most css class names in the PR seems very general. For example .left .right, .light, .dark these naming don't completely explain what they do, but a rule is created for each of these selectors. You could either use a namespaced naming pattern like timeline-left, timeline-right, section-dark, section-light, or you can make the rules more specific by selecting with more classes, such as .timeline.left, .timeline.right, .section.dark, .section.light.

I like how Bootstrap name things, although it's too well-known for word abbreviation to be proper. See https://getbootstrap.com/docs/3.4/css/

2 comments
1) Please don't abbreviate words in method naming, use generateRandomFact() instead.
2) General suggestion no immediate fix required - While hovering on the button, the hover animation looks great, but since the height becomes different due to the additional border, the whole page is pushed down a little bit. Adding a default transparent border or adding a fixed height container might help, but up to you for the fix :)

author: Alfredhgoog
comment:
+1 here.

Be aware that servlets may handle requests in a multi-threaded mode, and class local variables is a type of shared resources that need to be designed with concurrency considered.

Quote documentation on HttpServlet:
_"Servlets typically run on multithreaded servers, so be aware that a servlet must handle concurrent requests and be careful to synchronize access to shared resources. Shared resources include in-memory data such as instance or class variables and external objects such as files, database connections, and network connections. See the Java Tutorial on Multithreaded Programming for more information on handling multiple threads in a Java program."_

https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/servlet/http/HttpServlet.html

comment: Common practice is to use classes instead of IDs where possible (IDs can be important for JS and anchor links, but all CSS can be done using classes). author: cwlarson-google
comment:
aria-describedBy takes in the ID of an element whose text/value you want to be read by screenreaders.  You don't have an element with id="userName", so this doesn't do anything here.

If you want to provide a screenreader value, you can use `aria-label="My screenreader value here..."` instead.  Note, aria tags are pretty complex only work on certain elements, so I'm not sure they even work on inputs

comment:
We usually recommend against hardcoding index numbers like this. Since your json element is really dependent on the order in which this information is passed, I would recommend looking into using json+gson objects (https://sites.google.com/site/gson/gson-user-guide#TOC-Object-Examples)
That way, you are not relying on user[0] always having your first name, and user[1] always having the last name, etc.
Instead, you can use user.firstName and user.lastName, and same for birthday and major

author: ghandre
comment:
The sidebar seems to be duplicated in each file.

In general, we want to avoid duplication since it increases maintenance burdens and is highly error prone (someone editing the code later on will have to find and edit all the copies correctly, but will often mess one up without noticing; Over time this gets compounded and leads to systems that are impossible to work with).

It will be a bit more challenging, but could you find a way to share this logic between files? There's several ways to go about it, traditionally one would use an iframe, but now (html5) the simplest approach is probably a link/rel. My personal preference would be to create this in a script (and then share the script), using dom manipulation to build the nav programatically (though this isn't usually how most sites do it).

You should find how to do this with a search like "include html from another file", but also check out w3schools dom manipulation totorial if you're interested in the latter approach.

If you'd like to work on this in a seperate pull that's fine.

author: jerrychangusa
comment:
Something to consider: It is also possible to use a single servlet (e.g. /comments) which supports both doGet() and doPost(). 

If the components change independently, then it usually cleaner to keep the logic separate. However if they change together, then grouping them together may be easier to maintain.

author: jerrychangusa
comment:
To make this easier to maintain, consider separating the logic that deals with Datastore from the logic that handles the PostRequest through a new function. 

One other benefit is that if you decide to use a different database (e.g. Firebase, MongoDB) later on you would only need to update the function related to writing to the database.

author: ghandre
comment:
request.getParameter can return null if the request reaching the backend doesn't contain the field. Note that this is different than when a user using your site normally omits to fill in one of the fields (where you get a an empty string "", which you address).

It's fine to reject insane queries (they might be created by someone trying to break your system, a bug, or different versions of your software clashing together), but you should check for it (at present, if request.getParameter returns a null -- which a malicious user can force -- the 'value.equals' statement below will throw an exception.

Consider checking for value == null explicitly, maybe replacing it with the default value (or issuing some error and dropping the request, up to you).

author: ghandre
comment: dito regarding null checks. If you're interested, check out defensive programming, the idea that you should always program as if someone is actively trying to break your system. It makes code ugly, but is the only real way to build systems above a few thousand lines, IMO.

author: ghandre
comment:
Adding to the previous discussion on parsing, though indeed, your interface's users can't select negative or non-numeric values, they can manually call these methods here in the servlet backend by mimicking your post requests (but with bad values).

I'd suggest catching the NumberFormatException that parseInt can generate, and also checking it's of a sane size. Not checking for this can allow attackers to bring down your service (for instance, by requesting you serve millions of comments per request, and thousands of requests per second).

author: ghandre
comment: I *think* it's recommended to create a single instance of 'datastore', (e.g.: as a private class member), and then reuse that (though documentation isn't explicit on this, as far as I've found).

author: ghandre
comment:
Hm, this tabulates the votes each time you need to render the page which could potentially become very costly if there's millions of votes. Instead of recording individual votes, could you fetch the current count, and then increment it in your doPost method?

If you're interested in a bit more of a challenge/learning exercise (one which is quite relevant to day to day work we do with server programming), one catch to the above is the race condition you'd get if two people try to vote at the same time:
- Suppose the count for some country is 5;
- User A votes, which would cause your servlet to read the value 5, and increment it to 6
- But before it has a chance to write the result (6) to the datastore, User B votes.
- User B still sees the old value 5 in datastore, and increments its copy to 6.
- Now A writes storing 6 in the datastore
- Now B writes, storing 6 in the datastore again

This can happen because the servlet is multithreaded. Here's a video explaining the problem and the "synchronized" term in java:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RH7G-N2pa8M
If marking the doPost method as synchronized doesn't work, a synchronized block might work instead.

* Just because you use Java does not mean YOUR code needs to have the Apache license
* Depending on how open source you want your code to be, some flavor of a gnu public license might be more appropriate
* Generally you put your license once in the readme instead of in each code header (otherwise it clutters things up to have a long header in a bunch of places)

In general I think that your name validation might be too strict.

* If people put their full names, it could easily be longer than 12 characters 
* Many common names contain apostrophes, dashes, umlauts, etc

I think requiring a length greater than 2 is reasonable (though you got your comparison backwards I think).

author: ganewman42
comment:
See above for discussion of name validation.

Generally if you're going to validate inputs, you should do it in one place so that you don't accidentally get them out of sync later. Choose whether you'd rather do it in the front end or backend (either makes sense for different reasons).

author: ganewman42
comment: This name is a bit of a misnomer: It not only validates the form, but also saves the data if validation passes. validateAndSave or something similar might be more appropriate. If you decide to put data checks on the backend, saveComment might be a good choice.

author: ganewman42
comment:
I'm not a JavaScript expert, but I feel like you might have some excessive async functions throughout this file. Basically what many of these functions do are some quick operations like getting parameters and then block on the slowest operation (the get/post). As a result, you don't get any benefit from the asynchronous behavior that I can see, since you're still waiting for each operation in turn. However, you've taken on the complexity of asynchronous behavior into your error reporting.

In summary, think about what value this asynchronous behavior is bringing to you. Is that value worth the resulting complexity? I'll do some more research on what's recommended here as well and get back to you.

author: hieudan225
comment: After a bit of research, I thought that the front end validation was necessary because otherwise invalid data would be sent to the server and exceptions would be throw out all the times. On the other hand, I also thought back end validation was necessary because otherwise, evil people would be able to get around the front end validation and send hazardous data to the server. On this post (https://www.quora.com/Should-I-sanitize-inputs-clientside-or-serverside), I've seen similar arguments as well. So that was my thought, but it is easy to mess up if both sides aren't in sync like you said. What is your thought?

> > When it says "restarting server" does that mean rerunning "mvn package appengine:run"?
> 
> Yep. If you store anything in memory, when a server restarts, all of the data stored in memory will be cleared and lost. In this walkthrough, you are storing your data in Google Cloud Datastore, which is an external database. So even when you restart your server, the data will be persisted in that database to be read later.

When I rerun the "mvn package appengine:run" command all of the previous comments are lost. Any idea what I'm doing wrong?

author: tonymai
comment:
> When it says "restarting server" does that mean rerunning "mvn package appengine:run"?

Yep. If you store anything in memory, when a server restarts, all of the data stored in memory will be cleared and lost. In this walkthrough, you are storing your data in Google Cloud Datastore, which is an external database. So even when you restart your server, the data will be persisted in that database to be read later.

author: yjzhang111
comment: I use this variable to get around not being able to pass in user input to doGet. So whenever user enters a number (of comments to display), it first calls doPost, and doPost update this counter variable. Then the page calls doGet, which now has access to this counter variable to update the corresponding comments to display. I saw this method in the technical support chat, but I am not sure if there is a better way to do it.

comment:
To avoid resource leakage, when opening file handlers, they should be done within try-catch block to catch any exceptions and close the resource in case the handling fails.

see:
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/tryResourceClose.html
https://www.baeldung.com/java-try-with-resources#replacing

author: arjun-garg-google
comment: I would recommend defining an authentication response class, and returning an object of that class instead of using an array like this. The array approach requires the caller to know how this API is implemented, i.e. it must know what each value at each index corresponds to. Returning a well structured json object does not, and makes the response easy to extend in the future.

comment: To improve the readability in these files, a best practice is to have a line length limit at which you'd wrap any overflowing characters onto the next line. On our team, we use a 100 character line length limit (that includes whitespace). I think GitHub shows 125 characters in its diff view, so anything beyond that is hidden unless you scroll horizontally. If you're using an IDE, you should be able to adjust as setting to enforce this!

author: jessicaslaughter
comment:
This is a good use of whitespace in that you separated this "welcome-wrapper" section from the "part" section below, both of which are logical, large chunks of code, so adding the space improves the readability of the file. 

In general, try to save whitespace (blank lines) for when you're separating these types of logical chunks of code. Too much whitespace means those chunks don't stand out anymore, so the readability benefit is lost (it also leads to really long files!). As a reviewer, I want to be able to scan through the template and easily notice the different features on the page!

author: geekster777
comment: You never remove this event listener. After you type the search twice, clicking next will call this method twice with two different contexts (the one from your first search and the one from your second search). You should probably make file level variables for your counter and input. Then you can reset them whenever you search but only have to assign this event listener once.

author: jessicaslaughter
comment: Even though you're doing all server-side work on this branch, you should still create a separate PR every time you want us to review new work. Once a PR has been sent out for review, you shouldn't add any new functionality to it since we're actively reviewing the original code. So instead of committing new work to a PR that's already being reviewed, you should create a new one and add us as reviewers once it's in a state that you want it to be reviewed.

author: jessicaslaughter
comment: If you want us to wait on reviewing this one until you think it's got everything you want in it (while keeping it small), you can just remove us from the reviewers list and we'll wait!

author: seunomonije
comment: So I'm gonna have to have a bunch of branches and then delete them once I'm done right? It also makes sense with rebasing now

author: jessicaslaughter
comment: Yup! Ideally you'd have a branch 1 that points to master with some changes, and another branch 2 that points to branch 1 with different changes, and each branch eventually has a PR with all its commits. Once the branch 1 PR is reviewed and accepted, you push it to master, fix any merge conflicts in branch 2, and rebase that branch 2 to point to master.

author: geekster777
comment:
use triple equals (`===`) when comparing values. `==` tends to be ambiguous and has unintuitive results:
```
[] == '' // true
[] == false // true
{} == true // true
```
https://www.destroyallsoftware.com/talks/wat (start at 1:20).
If you use triple equals, all of these are false instead of true, which is what most developers expect.

nit: Indentation here is 4 spaces instead of 2 as in most of the rest of the file. Google's style guide uses 2. You can un-indent the div.content too to make it clear it's a sibling of the img. Same applies to a few other instances in the file below.

In my opinion the best way to deal with code formatting is to automate it. I've found [Prettier](https://prettier.io/) great for web dev. I'm not sure if it'll integrate into your current workflow but if you get VS Code working there's a Prettier plug-in you can use to format on save, really nice for freeing up all your attention for solving the problem at hand without overhead like formatting to distract you.

author: VivekShankar
comment:
Here and below - when passing literal parameters, adding a comment like /* parameterName= */ can make the code more readable. 

Here's a snippet from the Java Style Guide: 


In certain contexts literal arguments - such as 0, "", true and false, or null - can make it difficult for readers to know what a method will do. We generally discourage defining methods that take boolean parameters or otherwise expect users to pass in ambiguous literals. However, when you must call such a method you're encouraged to use the parameter name as an inline comment at the call site, so that readers don't need to look at the method declaration to understand the parameter's purpose.

Such a comment should be formatted in this way:

`booleanMethod(/* enableFoo= */ true);`

comment: I'd recommend putting these in an event listener for something like [`DOMContentLoaded`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/DOMContentLoaded_event) in your script to separate content from behavior (https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html#Separation_of_Concerns);

author: geoffbass

author: steven-solar
comment:
WIll do! Didn’t realize that this violated separation of concerns (assumed it was equivalent to giving a css class to html element). But this makes sense and would be cleaner (especially with calling multiple functions). 

Did some reading into different handlers I could use for this and it seems the one you recommended, DOMContentLoaded, is better than others. I considered using the window.onload attribute, but read that this only fires once everything is loaded (dom, css, external images, etc) whereas DOMContentLoaded will fire as soon as the dom tree is ready, which in this case I think is better practice. Not sure how much it matters as there's minimal content to load anyways, but thought I'd share what I found.

author: geoffbass
comment:
Looks like this was introduced in a previous PR, but avoid `innerHTML` in general as it can be an [XSS attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting) vector. I think gson does sanitization but it's good practice to avoid it. `innerText` is generally safer.

I'd recommend using the DOM API to create these spans (specifically [`document.createElement`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/createElement) and then set their innerText, then append the new elements to the div container. I'm happy to provide more guidance on this if you have questions or get stuck.

author: VivekShankar
comment:
Nice job meeting the "arrange, act, test" model of writing Java unit tests at Google! 

In case you're interested... the arrange step is for setting up details of the external world specific to the situation under test (e.g. in this case, initializing the `Greeter`). 

The act step is where you actually make calls to the class/object under test .

The assert step is the place to make assertions on the return values collected.

We usually leave a blank line in between the arrange, act, and test steps - which you've already done!

author: jbir789
comment:
This looks good. However, it's a bit difficult to see what the page looks like from raw HTML / CSS. Could you share a link to the live page so we can see the rendered page? You can follow [these instructions](https://github.com/shivanighanta/my-portfolio/blob/master/walkthroughs/week-2-web-development/portfolio-walkthrough.md#live-server), or alternatively attach a screenshot.

A few more comments:
  - Your PR description is excellent: it is detailed without being too extensive (which is good) and we can immediately know what was changed from reading it.
  - The title could be a bit more descriptive. In the current state, reading the PR title isn't enough to understand what the PR addresses (which functionality is being added?). This is important, because people search for PRs / commits by looking at the first line / title, and not the description. My recommendation is to have a title that's a good descriptive 1-line description of the PR, and take advantage of the description to fill in any extra info relevant to the change.

author: jbir789
comment:
Most software development projects have a maximum number of characters per line, which is intended to keep the content of the code visible without needing to scroll to the right to read it. This helps making development and code reviews easier.

Github allows for a max of 125 visible characters in code reviews, so I would recommend to stay within that range for clarity purposes.

You can find the recommended guidelines for Google HTML projects at https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html. Some noteworthy items:

- [the indentation is recommended to be 2 spaces](https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html#Indentation) (I see from 4 spaces to 6 spaces in this file, which results in more easily going over the character limit.
 - [Breaking long lines is optional for HTML](https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html#HTML_Line-Wrapping), but this is a good practice to follow as it applies to most languages / projects.

author: sooniln
comment:
writing comments is a dark art, where you want to avoid both over commenting and under commenting. A good rule of thumb, is to consider your code as if someone else was reading it, and then ask yourself, "could a programmer a little below my level understand what's happening here?". if the answer is no, first see if you can make your code more clear. if that doesn't help, then consider a comment.

to apply that to the comment here:
"execute the function" - it should be obvious to another programmer that this is executing a function, so this part of the comment is not helpful
"show all columns" - is this obvious? perhaps... but i would say it could be made more obvious by renaming the argument of filterSelection(...). "c" is not a descriptive name below, but "columns" or something like that might be. if you rename this to columns, then a reader can look at filterSelection, and it becomes obvious this is filtering comments - and then they have understood everything that's in the comment, and it becomes no longer necessary.

author: sooniln
comment: If you have some free time, look up 'hungarian notation' and what that is. Basically it's the idea of including type information (like 'array') in a variable name. It's fallen out of favor, and is generally avoided in strongly typed languages. Since JS is a weakly typed language, I have no problems with it here.

author: sooniln
comment:
the code in both branches of this if statement is almost identical. is there a way you can change the logic so that the if statement isn't necessary?

generally when writing code we want to avoid unnecessary branching - branching is harder code to read and understand because now your reader has to keep more possibilities in their head, one for each branch of the if statement. many times branching is good of course - but if it's possible to trivially eliminate branches then that is generally preferred.

comment: It looks like your indentation got messed up somehow. Per the Google style guide, you should indent 2 spaces at a time: https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html#Indentation. If you are using a custom editor, it could be that it has it's default indentation set to 4 spaces instead of two. Also, the closing tag should be at the same indentation as the opening tag.

author: peizhaoou
comment:
Also, as Marti mentioned in the weekly sync, a general practice is to make each commit smaller. For example, you added a few blocks in this, conact_me page, gallery, meme, etc., which can be seen as functional units added together, but can also be separated logically.

The reason to spreading commits to more self-contained units is (1) easier to review and spot an error and (2) if something needs to be reverted for some reason, we can just revert the relevant parts.

author: peizhaoou
comment:
You can refer to the open-sourced Google Java style guide for more thorough reference, but in general, in Java, we would use camel case, e.g., "toJson".

The same also applies to method names, e.g., prefer convertToJson(). About the name part "Gson" in the method name, you could keep it like "convertToJsonWithGson" if you think using Gson is something particularly important for the caller to be aware of; otherwise, prefer a shorter name without exposing the underlying implementation details with "convertToJson".

In general, we push for a consistent style guide to make it easy for everyone to read the code more easily. This is especially important when you work with a big team. Also, code is read way more often than written.

author: peizhaoou
comment:
Nit: usually if a local variable is not used elsewhere except in a return statement, it'd be good to avoid it in the first place so that readers don't need to remember one more variable. Just do:

return gson.toJson(arrayList);

author: peizhaoou
comment:
Nit: (1) please use camel case with a starting lower case for variable; (2) please use a more specific name for variables, e.g., wordArray, or something else if you prefer.

Also ArrayList is a core Java class. Even for a class name, you would want to avoid defining a class with this exact name.

author: peizhaoou
comment:
For now, it may be fine to use an array with hard-coded size, especially when you just started.

Going forward, try to think how you could avoid this. Think about the situation where the server side may be updated to output more objects, then your client code needs to change. Not to mention if object size is dynamic.

Thanks Andrew for making the change. Now that it all looks more of nitpicks that you hopefully already know how to address, I will approve it.

My intention is that the code author then doesn't need to wait for another review round-trip time to get the approval. So I'd suggest fixing open comments before you submit even if you got approval. Have fun hacking!)

It's a good policy in general to stick to one way of defining the colors. Either all as rgba or all as hex codes.

On a general note, we want things to be consistent across the code.

author: hayleejane3
comment:
Since you're playing with color and opacity quite a bit here, I would recommend adding a comment describing what you're trying to accomplish.

There's 2 reasons for this:
1. Helps reviewers (or other people looking at this) get an idea of what they're looking for(or at)
2. You might not remember what you were doing here and why you did something when you come back to this code 3 years from now. Things may seem trivial right now since everything is fresh in your mind, but it won't be the same when you're working on something completely different at a later point.

Just some convention:

1. The first sentence should say: "A servlet..."
2. End all comments with "." to keep them consistent
3. TODO should come on the next line.
4. Another rule we follow here about TODOs is assigning them to yourself with your ldap, so this would look something like this:

```suggestion
/*
 * Servlet that returns some example content. 
 * TODO(ntarn): Modify this file to handle comments data.
 */
```

author: hayleejane3
comment:
I guess my point was that you're customizing this site to be your own, so you can name things to be more appropriate to what purpose they serve. The tutorials would use more literal names to describe what they're trying to teach you, i.e. teach you about hardcoding messages. But since you know that you're hardcoding messages and these messages serve 'x' purpose, you could say something like xMessages or x<something>. 
Basically relevant to what it is, since you can have more than one instance of hardcoded messages. So you want to be as specific about each one as possible.

comment:
I would move this comment to the exact line(s) that do this. 

That's because this entire block in itself does more than just the grayscale. You're applying general styles to the entire element. 

The comment would be outside if the CSS rules in the block were all exclusively for the grayscaling. In which case, the class name would also be something like .grayscale{...} and then you could reuse it in multiple places to grayscale a lot of things.

author: andres-holguin
comment:
This is actually for a new issue 😆  it showed up when I tried to include a Login/Logout button in the header.
The image upload problem seems to be a bigger issue. Sometimes fetch() requests will just get [stuck on pending ](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44207690/84394886-82d61380-abcb-11ea-83f8-e323422c181c.png) and never resolve. I'm going to test if the same issue occurs on a deployed server, tomorrow. If it continues, I have a feeling it might have to do with not `await`ing the fetches, which means I'd have to make my functions ["Async all the way up"](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29808915/why-use-async-await-all-the-way-down)

author: andres-holguin

author: elefeint
comment:
Looks great! A few comments/questions included. 

I also used GitHub's suggestion functionality to fix a typo -- mainly to show that this functionality, while useful, can throw a wrench into a habitual git workflow. If you accept a suggestion, github will commit the change. If you then modify the same file locally and try to commit & push, you may find a conflict! So the safest way to accept reviewers' PR edits is to `git pull` immediately after accepting them.

Perhaps there is opportunity to reuse the repeating navigation structure, but that is out of scope for this PR.

author: elefeint
comment:
Since those are hardcoded, there is no need to remove and recreate them on every request. On the other hand, you will likely replace this with datastore-sourced data soon.

I would either initialize `comments` with hardcoded values when initilaizing it (`Arrays.asList()` is the easiest way to initialize a list inline) or turn `comments` into a local variable. I'd favor the latter because HTTP handlers should be _stateless_ -- they should behave the same way for each identical request. As it happens, neither `ArrayList` nor `WebServlet` are thread-safe, so if you spawn multiple simultaneous requests to `/data`, you might see some very interesting behavior!

author: meltsufin
comment: Not a technical issue, but from the UX point of view, I would not choose an input box with a magic -1 input that needs to be explained. To avoid the -1, you can add a checkox to toggle whether to limit results at all, and only when checkbox is selected, enable the input value control. Some web sites also use a drop-down with pre-filled values like [all, 1, 5, 10, 25, 50], or something like that.

author: meltsufin
comment:
Nice addition with sort!

One thing to pay attention to is opportunities to reduce code duplication. For example, you have `BlogCommentsService` and a `CommentsService`. They are very similar. You can potentially replace them with a single `CommentsService`. However, this will only be possible if you make your `Comment` entity more rich with an additional attribute that would specify whether it is for the blog or the regular comments page. Then you can filter on that `type` attribute, depending on which page is using the comments. I hope this makes sense. The less code you have, the less testing you have to do, and the easier it is to maintain.

author: elefeint
comment: I'd recommend putting curly braces even if they are optional. It's in the official google style guide for Java, but I think it's even more important in Javascript because Javascript won't complain about a lot of syntax problems, hiding malformed code blocks that end up doing something completely unintended. It's a tiny habit, but it will save you hours of troubleshooting someday.

author: bsidhom
comment:
Checkboxes allow users to select an arbitrary number of star ratings all at once. Instead, it probably makes more sense to change these to radio buttons, only one of which can be selected at any time. For example:

```
<input type="radio" name="star-rating" id="one-star-button" value="1">
<label for="one-star-button">1</label>

<input type="radio" name="star-rating" id="two-star-button" value="2">
<label for="two-star-button">2</label>
...
```

author: bsidhom
comment:
Instead of fetching query parameter names in-line with strings, it's safer (and more readable) to put these in static constants that you can the reuse elsewhere. Putting all of these magic strings in one place makes it easier for you to verify that the parameters as defined in your HTML match the server parameter names.

For example:

```
private static final String NAME_QUERY_PARAM = "name-input";
...

private ArrayList<Comment> theComments = ...
...
String name = getParameter(request, NAME_QUERY_PARAM, "");
```

author: bsidhom
comment:
You can remove `movieVotes.put` now that you're using `movieVotes.merge`.

Here's an overview of the relevant `Map` methods, which I think make the semantics of `merge` clearer:
* `get(key)`: Retrieves the value for the given key, if any
* `getOrDefault(key, default)`: Retrieves the value for the given key if it exists. Otherwise, returns the default value. Does not update the map. (I would have recommended using this method if you were not updating the map immediately afterward.)
* `put(key, value)`: Modifies the map in-place by setting the given key to the given value. Returns the value _previously_ associated with the given key (or null). (You obviously don't need to use the return value here since you're just modifying the map and not reading anything back.)
* `[merge(key, value, remappingFunction)](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/docs/api/java/util/Map.html#merge-K-V-java.util.function.BiFunction-)`: Sets the given `key` to the given `value` if there's no value already associated. If there is already an associated value, then `remappingFunction` is called with the old value and new value as arguments; the key is associated with the return value of `remappingFunction`. In the case of `ConcurrentHashMap`.

In the case of `ConcurrentHashMap`, the entire `merge` operation happens atomically. In other words, it allows you to to retrieve an old map value and update the map using a computation over the old value all in one step, while maintaining thread-safety. Since you don't use this result to perform other updates that need to happen synchronously, it's safe to use a single `merge` operation here instead of synchronizing over multiple update operations.

Setting `movieVotes.put(animatedMovie, numVotes)` is not technically incorrect in the context of this specific thread, since it just re-sets `animatedMovie` to point to `numVotes` (which it already should have after the call to `merge`). Unfortunately, this opens up the code to bad interleavings ([race conditions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_condition)) which might introduce errors.

For example, suppose that 2 different users are adding a vote for "Shrek" at the same time, from different computers. Say that, before either of these users votes, `numVotes` for "Shrek" is 1. Now the first user's request comes in, and `movieVotes.merge()` runs successfully and the value of "Shrek" (number of votes) is 2. Now suppose that the second user's vote request comes in and also runs `merge`, meaning that the value is now 3. However, suppose that the second user's request thread executes `movieVotes.put()` next. This re-sets the count of Shrek to 3, which it already was, so no problem yet. Finally, the first thread continues executing `movieVotes.put()` (suppose that the thread was sleeping during this time). Recall that the first thread had originally set the vote count to 2, which means that `numVotes` is currently 2. The call to `movieVotes.put()` runs successfully and the count for "Shrek" is now 2 again! We started with a count of 1, processed two vote requests ("successfully") and ended with a count of 2--one of the votes was effectively dropped.

author: scottymb
comment:
Sorry if this comment comes through in two different forms, but it looks like I lost my original...

I'd actually suggest that you don't need the custom tags you've made, particularly `intro-title` and `cursive`. Some reasons: 1) in your case, it's simple and direct to just style `h1` and `h2` in your CSS. `h1` already suggests that it's a top-level heading like a title, so having the extra tag to describe it may not be too useful. 2) Regarding the `cursive` tag, usually it's a good idea not to have anything in your HTML that suggests visual appearance, that way you can choose to change that appearance in the future (let's say by un-cursiving the text) by just updating one CSS rule, and you don't have to go through and change every instance you've added `cursive` in the HTML.

author: scottymb
comment: I suggest not using a `br` here. If you need extra space between the `h1` and the button, you can add margin either to the bottom of `h1` or to the top of your button.

author: scottymb
comment:
Hehe, looks like the comment might have gotten lost along the way. The summary is that I think you can remove the custom tags you created and just directly style h1, h2, h3, and button. But again, it's optional for this - enjoy your Friday. I'll copy the original comment below:

---

I'd actually suggest that you don't need the custom tags you've made, particularly intro-title and cursive. Some reasons: 1) in your case, it's simple and direct to just style h1 and h2 in your CSS. h1 already suggests that it's a top-level heading like a title, so having the extra tag to describe it may not be too useful. 2) Regarding the cursive tag, usually it's a good idea not to have anything in your HTML that suggests visual appearance, that way you can choose to change that appearance in the future (let's say by un-cursiving the text) by just updating one CSS rule, and you don't have to go through and change every instance you've added cursive in the HTML.

author: qi-google
comment: I would move `<meta>` and `<link>` into the `<head>` element. [See](https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_meta.asp). In this way, the `font-awesome.min.css` will stay with the existing `style.css`. By the way, `font-awesome` is an awesome library!

author: qi-google
scottymb
comment: Prefer using `em` instead of `i` and `strong` instead of `b`. This goes back to the idea of not having visual style information in your HTML - `i` and `b` specify the visual styles of italicized and bolded. `em` and `strong`, on the other hand, describe emphasis and strength without prescribing a particular look, so you could choose to restyle those however you wanted in the future without needing to update HTML.

author: scottymb
comment:
`head` must be outside and before the `body` element - see the examples in https://www.w3schools.com/html/html_intro.asp, but your basic layout is always going to be:

Doctype
html
- head /head
- body /body
/html

author: genedwards
comment:
I'm on the fence, but I think it's worth having photo.date be a `Date` object rather than a string that represents a date.
The input is very flexible so you can set `date: new Date('Apr 26 2020')` or `date: new Date('04-26-2020')`. Then, you can replace `monthToNum` with `NumToMonth` to format your output.

Having a real Date as the data source means incorrect inputs can be caught at compile time instead of run time. For example, if you have `Sep 4, 2020` will throw an error with this current set up, but it will not be caught until run time.

author: genedwards
comment:
Unfortunate that you don't have access to our internal best practice guides. But keep in mind that the naming of these existing tests do not follow our best practice for testing.

> Each test should explicitly name not only the method being tested, but also the expected outcome and sometimes specific details of the state or input being tested.

For example, I would name these last 2 tests `query_onlyOptionalAttendees_returnsAvailableTime` `query_onlyOptionalAttendeesWithNoAvailableTime_returnsNoTimes`.
No need to change since you're just following existing convention in the code you're modifying.

Here's an external guide I found. https://qualitycoding.org/unit-test-naming/
The most important thing is the expected result and the condition of the test. When someone else makes changes to your code, if you didn't state the expected result, they can end up modifying your test *just to make the test pass* but the test may not be testing what it's meant to. Happens all the time.

author: jiaxinz-g
jiaxinz-g
comment:
```suggestion
  private List<String> messages = new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList("one", "two", "three"));
```

This is not Google style guide, but a common best practice. Declaring the variable type to be a more generic interface makes it more flexible. The same as in method parameters. Imagine there is a method that takes LinkedList, then this variable can not be passed into this method. But if both variable and method parameter are declared as List, then you can use this method to process this variable.

author: gagomez
comment: A great step in the right direction! One thing I would recommend to keep going is to move all database logic to the query helper. Imagine a query helper that returns a list of `Comment` (an object that doesn't exist yet) and has a method for deleting a `Comment`! In this case, the servlets no longer need to know anything about the datastore including the property names!

author: gagomez
comment:
Doing initialization work (in this case expensive because we are querying a database in it) can lead to trouble. From an API perspective, it's difficult to convey that a constructor is executing a query so it could lead to mis-usages (e.g. creating a QueryHelper but then not using the results).

In general, I avoid doing any work in a constructor outside of setting fields. You can do this work when `getResults` and `deleteAllEntries` is called. Feel free to put this in a helper method.

author: gagomez
comment:
Yeah that's awesome that you are thinking about flexibility! Having said that, I have found that it's good to add flexibility where there is an existing case (via refactoring) or for something you know you will need soon in the future. (I've learned this lesson the hard way)

Note that creating a CommentQueryHelper specific to comments can be refactored later to be flexible if the API it exposes is flexible (e.g. having methods like getResults(), deleteEntity(), addEntity()).

author: lazau-g
comment:
Thanks for letting me know Gus that HTML forms don't support DELETE verbs https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/114156/why-are-there-are-no-put-and-delete-methods-on-html-forms.

To update: it's more important to use the POST/REDIRECT/GET pattern than the right HTTP verb.

author: gusteran
comment:
Good to know. I'll implement POST/REDIRECT/GET. 

To clarify about CommentList, it was intended to be a wrapper class to make it easy to turn a sorted list of comments and along with the total number of comments into a json. The total number of comments was included such that only the sublist of comments needed by the page had to be sent to allow for the javascript to list the accurate number of pages.

I have modified the CommentList to no longer include the excess variable and instead handle it's inclusion in the creation of the json on the servlet. I am keeping the class as it allows the comments to be sorted.

author: lazau-g
comment:
A standard pattern for web pages is POST/REDIRECT/GET (or DELETE/REDIRECT/GET). Read about it more here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post/Redirect/Get.

So here you'd respond with a redirect back to the same page.

author: lazau-g
comment:
When switching to the POST/REDIRECT/GET or the analogous DELETE/REDIRECT/GET pattern - don't attach an onclick JS handler to the button, just create a form that submits the POST/DELETE request for the button.

An additional benefit of going with that pattern is that you'll have less JS code managing the comments.

comment:
Instead of "hide the comments", it might be better to "show the comments only if the users is logged in".

If for some reasons, /login has a high latency, users will see the comments show up first and disappear later. That is typically a janky experience.

If you "show the comments async", it is better because it is basically "lazy load comments, which is not needed for the initial page".

author: fenghaolw
comment:
I wonder what is the value of json in the server -- there are few possibilities for why `resp.json()` is null:

- `gson.toJson(null)` returns an empty string, therefore the response is empty. `resp.json()` in the client does not see any json data to parse, so it returns null.
-  `gson.toJson(null)` returns "null" (as a string), so the response is "null". `resp.json()` in the client see this and parse it as null.
- `gson.toJson(null)` returns null (non-string), and the response is "null".

I feel like it is probably not a good idea to depends on nullability?

author: fenghaolw
comment:
Since all you need is a falsey value, you could directly write an empty string in the response (instead of using gson.toJson?)?

IMO the null and "null" conversion is confusing and unnecessary.

author: surbhimadan1995
comment:
Lets add a param tag to "anonymous" here, which would make this line look like:
this(/* name= */ "anonymous", content);

We use these param tags that contain the argument name used in the method declaration (which is "name" in this case) when its not clear from the passed in value ("anonymous") what its referring to. the second argument "content" is self-evident so its not needed for that. 

Another common example for when param tags are good is when multiple arguments have the same type - so consider a class with constructor Point(int x, int y)
and then someone in another class instantiates a Point object:
new Point(1, 3);
instead of this if they did:
new Point(/* x= \*/ 1, /* y= */ 3); it would be immediately clear to readers which number is the x and which is the y coord and also help the author not accidentally switch the order of the args (which as you can tell in this case, the compiler would be just fine with since they;re both ints)

author: kpancha
comment:
There are only two times that post can get called-- when someone leaves a comment or when a comment is liked. In the first case, there will always be a comment and a name parameter in the req body (though either could be an empty string), hence why we check for content and name != null in the first if statement (adding a new comment). In the latter case, the key is always passed in the request body so this is how we know it is a "like". 

Since post can only be called these two times it works with the code I have written but it isn't very self explanatory or adaptable so any other suggestions are welcome :)

author: surbhimadan1995
comment:
Lets add some nicer logging for these errors -- check out this util class: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/logging/Logger.html 
Essentially you have a logger instance per class type: 
private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(DataServlet.class.getName()); 

so then there are different "levels" of logging  - https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/logging/Level.html because sometimes we just need informational logging vs when exceptions happen so maybe Id put this as warning level 
logger.log(Level.WARNING, "Entity was not found in the datastore: " + e.getMessage())

We want to use standard frameworks for these types of things as opposed to printlns because on a larger scale when lots of different kinds of things are logged (for info or warning or error purposes - standardisation enables users to filter the logs when they need to look at what happened easily:))

comment: I fixed it, it had to do with what the datastore of storing. The issue was if the datastore has comments from a deleted post, then it wont post any of the comments because it would try appending a comment to a null post which breaks everything. I just think this means i need to find a way to store my blog posts also in the datastore so when a blog post is deleted, all the comments and other stuff in the datastore also get deleted. Done.

author: wli
comment:
1. `comment == ""` is a java gotcha. This will always be false because java is doing reference comparison here, and not a string value comparison. This should be `comment.isEmpty()` instead.
2. Once you do change point 1 above, you will then need to do the nullcheck first because you don't want a null pointer exception.

author: astrelni
comment:
This comparison will return false when text is undefined. Here you'll want: `if (!text)`.

When calling `deleteComments()` with no arguments, `author`, `date`, `text`, and `emotion` will be undefined. When converting them to a string, they have the special behavior of being converted to `"undefined"`, which is what you depend on in the data servlet. But comparing an undefined object to the string `"undefined"` will not cause the undefined object to be converted to a string before comparison.

author: oydang
comment:
You can also do: `if (text === undefined)` to compare the text to the global `undefined` variable: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/undefined

Using '===' over '==' is in the style guide: https://google.github.io/styleguide/jsguide.html#features-equality-checks

author: astrelni
comment:
This may be too paranoid in practice, but it may be good to generate the UUID inside a loop and query the datastore to check for a collision with a previous comment. I realize the probability is ridiculously low, but doing it properly makes us not depend on the implementation since the API doesn't guarantee no collisions.

pseudocode of what I mean:
```
id = new uuid
while id collides:
  id = new uuid
```

author: oydang
comment: Any reason you're choosing to store the UUID as a string vs a UUID object?

In the real world you would disable partially complete features until they are fully complete and then flip a flag to make the full feature visible, but you don't have to go through all the process of creating a flippable feature flag for this.

author: aokeke
comment:
This logic is a bit difficult to follow. Could use `Math.abs(...)` again here to just check if the absolute value of the change in row <=1 and the absolute value of the change in col <=1. Like for the other cases you also need to make sure the selected_square is not the same as the current square, though.

Would anything have been wrong with 
`((square.row == (this.selected_square.row + 1) || square.row == (this.selected_square.row - 1)) && ( square.col == (this.selected_square.col + 1) || square.col == (this.selected_square.col - 1)))` ?

Also I would probably wrap the math on the right side of the equation with parentheses. Order of operation works correctly in this case, but just to be safe. I used to work using a language where everything was left to right. Absolutely no order of operation rules so now I guess I'm paranoid.

author: andrewlathamgoogle
comment:
Naming of this variable could be improved, for two reasons:

1. Unclear what div refers to.  It's the number of degrees between satellite centroids, right?  Someone reading your code isn't going to be able to glean that from div, so they'll have to look at the RHS of the assignment to understand what this variable actually does, and then recall that every time they see it reappear in the code.
2. More importantly, in this specific case, people are going to see this variable name and think it has something to do with a \<div\> element, which could lead to confusion if it gets used in an ambiguous context later on.

author: andrewlathamgoogle
comment:
This variable name is also unclear.

In general, imagine you're going to have to come back in six months to fix a bug in this code and want to be able to understand everything as fast as possible.  If you just see "numb", and don't remember what it means, you are going to have to parse the RHS of the assignment to understand what "numb" is supposed to be.  This case is especially instructive because in this hypothetical scenario you would have to trace through your code to remind yourself what "div" and "mathfunc" are meant to be which will make the task especially arduous.

author: andrewlathamgoogle
comment:
nit: parent-div

Not nit:  What is this the parent of?  It is not clear from the context, and furthermore if you add more content this will not be the only div used as a parent of other elements.  Something like satellite-icons-container is clearer.

author: andrewlathamgoogle
comment:
nit: be consistent about single-quotes vs. double-quotes.  Consistently do not use double quotes, per JS style guide 5.6.1 "use single quotes."

We have a static checker in the DV3 codebase that checks for single/double quote consistency per-file and crashes compilation if it fails... drives me nuts when I'm just trying to add debug log statements!

author: andrewlathamgoogle
comment:
The organization and CSS for this seems to only be designed for the single element.  For instance it is 150px x 150px but after you've positioned elements absolutely within it it takes up a lot more space, meaning the box model does not accurately represent its contents on the page.

Instead consider creating one div to contain all 7 of your elements, centering it vertically+horizontally on the page using flexbox, and dynamically positioning all 7 elements inside it.

author: andrewlathamgoogle
comment:
This assumption doesn't seem necessary.  You can treat a rectangular container as an ellipse and use (offsetWidth, offsetHeight) to get your x and y radii, then calculate x and y based on that.

If you are going to include this assumption, you should validate it, and handle the case where it is not satisfied.  Even if you just crash, that is better than providing an unpredictable user experience.

author: andrewlathamgoogle
comment:
This method name is misleading.  You're not just converting a coordinate to a string, you are also doing math on that coordinate to change its value.

Hypothetical example of why this would matter:  Your display is wrong, and another engineer comes in and tries to figure out why.  They know it must be something modifying the pixels, but as they're skimming your code they see "convertCoordinateToString" and think "ok I don't need to read that function because all it's doing is converting this to a string.  The error must be earlier."

I would suggest putting all the coordinate-related math in one place to make it easy to find/modify later on.

comment:
Since DataForm is used to secure data transaction in the frontend, only elements with the attribute "name" specified are sent to the backend, thus "name=" will always be there when we extract the request. 

Source: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12543848/does-form-data-still-transfer-if-the-input-tag-has-no-name

author: andrewlathamgoogle
comment:
What if I make the request to your endpoint myself and skip over your form?  Never underestimate the ability of the users to screw with your system.  Your server should work independently of the client since it's always possible to interact with the server bypassing the client entirely.

Thanksgiving 2017 I spent several days investigating a bug that, at the end of the day, was someone using a custom job to make requests to our server (probably some kind of scraper).  After we made some changes, their request was malformed, which our code didn't expect, and the default error handling behavior was to redirect.  Their job would then, evidently, retry the same URL, and the end result of this feedback loop was a huge spike in client errors for that particular page.

author: antmar

> > > Completed portfolio walkthrough. However, added more than one responsibility in a single PR because I was unaware of the inability to cherry pick commits to add to a PR. Will enforce smaller and more frequent PRs from now on.

I think the size of this PR was OK. README change could have gone in a separate PR, but it doesn't practically matter.

Another option is to squash your commits when creating a pull request, so they don't show up as individual entries on the 'master' branch: https://help.github.com/en/github/collaborating-with-issues-and-pull-requests/about-pull-request-merges#squash-and-merge-your-pull-request-commits

author: antmar
comment:
I suggest using a single class `column-left` and `column-right` instead of separate class `column`. You don't have a use case for separate `column`, `left`, or `right`, and something like `column-left` is more descriptive. If you need to apply a style to both columns, you can just list both classes in the selector.

https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html#ID_and_Class_Naming

author: antmar
comment:
The CSS class name should represent what element (group of elements) are. "me-size" describes the presentation (sets a size). Consider something like "portrait" or "top-image".

Better yet, make this an id, because the size is likely unique to this one element.

author: sperzion
comment: You can initialize this on the same line you declare it to avoid instantiating it every time the URL is hit. This helps performance.

author: sperzion
comment: This should probably have private static final keywords as well. Private keeps it only visible to this class. Static means it's shared across all instances of this class (though this might not be as necessary because there's likely only one instance of this class). Final means you won't be changing it.

author: sperzion
comment: You probably don't mean `static` for the comments field here. Static means that the field is shared across all instances of `DataServlet`. You're likely only ever going to have one instance, but for correctness, you should remove the `static` keyword for the comments field.

author: sperzion
comment: You probably don't need to hang on to this `StringBuffer`. You create a new one every time in `doPost` (which is necessary, since you don't want to retain state over calls to `doPost`), but it's only ever used in `doPost`. So it's safe to just keep this as a local variable within `doPost`.

author: sperzion

author: sperzion
comment: This line and the `subList` call below should be unnecessary. Assuming the `asIterable` call above properly returns no more than `numOfComments` number of comments, then `commentList` has the right number of comments. If, in the case you don't trust `asIterable` to return the right number of comments with the limit you have imposed, i.e. `commentList.size() > numOfComments`, then this if check is testing the incorrect condition. It should check if `commentList.size() > numOfComments` and then restrict the list of comments to the unmodified `numOfComments`.

author: sperzion
comment: I recommend moving `COMMENT` and your other comment-related constants to your `Comment` class as public, so you can reference them from `DataServlet` and `DeleteDataServlet`.

author: sperzion

author: sperzion
comment:
Isn't `numOfComments` supposed to be the number of comments the user is asking to see? Usually, that means at most that many comments at a time.

What this if check is doing is increasing the number of comments returned to the front end to the full number of comments.

As an example, say `numOfComments` as entered by the user is 5. Say you have stored 100 comments. This if statement would cause `numOfComments` to be 100.

author: lee12jin
comment:
Ah okay. Back when I was web developing, promises were the hot thing, and it was a huge improvement to callbacks. The reason being is that callbacks made code super hard to read since it required tons of nested functions.

Now, I think the latest craze is async/await as it makes the code even more readable than promises. I'd say go with async/await in the future but I'm not with the times in javascript. :)

author: lee12jin
comment: Are you sure you want a comments entity defined as User? If you are just adding Comments, I'd recommend just purely have a Comments class. If you want the name of the user, you can keep that but I think it would be better to hold off on doing user related work until you do the Authentication Walkthrough.  You can totally link comments to your own user defined entities as well but usually better to use IDs instead of name. That way you can separately add more fields to the user entity and still reference those fields from the comments entity without having to duplicate fields such as "name".

author: brucezheng
comment:
When naming ids/classnames, try to describe what the section is doing, not a "presentational attribute" like smaller text, etc. This will reduce refactoring if you decide to change styles later.

Here's what the style guide says

> Instead of presentational or cryptic names, always use ID and class names that reflect the purpose of the element in question, or that are otherwise generic.
> 
> Names that are specific and reflect the purpose of the element should be preferred as these are most understandable and the least likely to change.
> 
> Generic names are simply a fallback for elements that have no particular or no meaning different from their siblings. They are typically needed as “helpers.”

author: brucezheng
comment:
Nit: You can use block-like indentation (+2 on contents) for object literals ```{a, b, ...}``` and array literals ```[a, b, ...]```, but not function parameters ```(a, b, ...)```. For function parameters, you should follow normal line wrapping rules which is at least +4 on continuation lines from the original line ([documentation](https://google.github.io/styleguide/jsguide.html#formatting-indent)).

So, here for example, these would be valid ways to wrap:
```
gsap.fromTo('.circle-small', 
    {x: '10rem', opacity: 0}, 
    {x: '0', opacity: 1, ease:'back.out(1.7)', delay: 1.3});
```
or
```
gsap.fromTo(
    '.circle-small', 
    {x: '10rem', opacity: 0}, 
    {x: '0', opacity: 1, ease:'back.out(1.7)', delay: 1.3});
```
or
```
gsap.fromTo('.circle-small', 
            {x: '10rem', opacity: 0}, 
            {x: '0', opacity: 1, ease:'back.out(1.7)', delay: 1.3});
```
or

```
gsap.fromTo(
    '.circle-small', 
    {
      x: '10rem',
      opacity: 0,
    }, 
    {
      x: '0',
      opacity: 1,
      ease:'back.out(1.7)',
      delay: 1.3,
    });
```
(you get the idea...)

author: brucezheng

author: brucezheng
comment:
Nit: Try to avoid abbreviating Button to Btn as it diminishes readability.

> Give as descriptive a name as possible, within reason. Do not worry about saving horizontal space as it is far more important to make your code immediately understandable by a new reader. Do not use abbreviations that are ambiguous or unfamiliar to readers outside your project, and do not abbreviate by deleting letters within a word.

([documentation](https://google.github.io/styleguide/jsguide.html#naming-rules-common-to-all-identifiers))

author: brucezheng
comment: Let's global constant variables for colors so we know what is what. We cannot really do that for CSS without using a more sophisticated system like SASS, but we can in javascript.

author: brucezheng
comment:
Nit: Use function parameter comments when you can't tell from the arguments alone what parameters they are. That is, I can't from looking at the function call alone what ```#00bcd4``` and ```#ede7f6``` are.
```
fadeButton(
    '#portfolio-button',
    /* backgroundColor= */ '#00bcd4',
    /* borderColor= */ '#00bcd4',
    /* textColor=*/ '#ede7f6');
```
This is not the only way to solve this problem though. What you could do is have the second argument of ```fadeButton``` just be an object containing a bunch of options. Although at that point ```fadeButton``` is kind of just a pointless wrapper for ```gsap.to```. Another option is when you declare constants for colors, you could declare constants for functional names instead of descriptive names, that is, you could define
```
const PORTFOLIO_BUTTON_HOVER_TEXT_COLOR = '#ede7f6';
```
instead of 
```
const LIGHT_PURPLE = '#ede7f6';
```
Then the first call will look like
```
fadeButton(
    '#portfolio-button',
    PORTFOLIO_BUTTON_HOVER_BACKGROUND_COLOR,
    PORTFOLIO_BUTTON_HOVER_BORDER_COLOR,
    PORTFOLIO_BUTTON_HOVER_TEXT_COLOR);
```

author: brucezheng
comment:
The function name ```type``` could be more descriptive especially considering the word 'type' has other programming connotations.

Did you choose to implement this recursively because of setTimeout? The recursive element of this makes it a lot more difficult to follow.

I investigated this and found a possible workaround using ```async```/```await``` and promises: https://jsfiddle.net/01kgpeqt/

You use a ```sleep``` helper function that returns a promise and then ```await``` on that sleep function so you can write this kind of stuff iteratively.

author: brucezheng
comment: Doesn't this leave you in a state like ``` >Hi, my name is S ``` At some points? Instead you would want to step like: ``` [1] >Hi, my name is S [2] >Hi, my name is Sa [3] >Hi, my name is Sab ``` This is a really interesting micro implementation problem to solve - and a good candidate for creating a js library or something (which I bet exist already). We should make sure that the strategy we end up using here doesn't solve for a much "bigger" problem than necessary - the algorithm that could take any number of nested `````` tags requires creating a parse tree for ```text``` I think.

author: brucezheng
comment: See this article: https://medium.com/better-programming/back-end-data-validations-73ea9004c6d7

author: SabrinaSnider
comment:
I made changes so that there would be fewer server calls. The main ones are:

1. Seperated getComments() into two methods: getComments() which fetches comments from the server, and displayComments() which displays them on the front-end. This change was mostly for readability.
2. Combined the IsAdminServlet and GetUserServlet into one servlet called GetUserData. This returns both the email of the current user and the admin status. Since these values are usually used together, I figured it would be more efficient.
3. Fetched the user email and admin status prior to displaying individual comments for the fron-end. Before, the fetches were made when generating each comment, which caused extra unnecessary fetches.

author: SabrinaSnider
comment: Last commit was for deleting an old servlet (IsAdminServlet), which was replaced by GetUserDataServlet. 😊

author: brucezheng
comment:
We should also do a server side check to only delete a comment from the database if they have the sufficient permissions.

author: jesseelizabeth
comment:
Instead of a p tag, let's make this a label tag. This is recommended for accessibility purposes: https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_textarea.asp.

What do I mean by accessibility purposes? If a user was filling out this form using a screen reader, the screen reader wouldn't know that the p tag text was related to your textarea input. By adding a label for="whats a youtube video idea you have for me" and then in the textarea adding an id property that corresponds to this, the screen reader will be able to read out that this textarea is related to the 'whats a youtube video idea you have for me'.

author: jesseelizabeth
comment: You don't have to make your whole website completely accessible for this project, but it's really good to start thinking in this way. We always want to make sure we're building an application that can be accessible for everyone #BuildForEveryone :)

author: ljfranklin
comment: Delete these comments. You typically don't want comments that say *What* the code is doing, you want the what/how to be fairly obvious by reading the code itself. Comments can be useful for saying *Why* a bit of code exists if it's not obvious, e.g. "Return early here to avoid sending an unnecessary HTTP request". If you think the code is hard to read without a comment, consider instead writing a new helper function, e.g. `const movieline = pickRandomLine(lines);`.

author: ljfranklin
comment: Doing a string contains on the response is pretty brittle (likely to accidentally break). Instead use `response.sendError` on the server-side to return a status of 401 Unauthorized if the user isn't logged in. Then you can check `response.status` in the JS rather than doing a string contains.

author: evd123
comment:
I tried following: https://help.github.com/en/github/using-git/using-git-rebase-on-the-command-line#pushing-rebased-code-to-github
but ran into some issues... 
I tried: git rebase -i <commit #> with a couple of commits. Then, the link (above) said to save and close the editor and Git would reopen the editor. I'm not sure if Cloud Shell works exactly the same way as the terminal, because it didn't seem to reopen another editor. Then, I aborted the rebase to try again, and now get:

noop

Rebase ff40e76..ff40e76 onto ff40e76 (1 command)

Commands:
p, pick = use commit
r, reword = use commit, but edit the commit message
e, edit = use commit, but stop for amending
s, squash = use commit, but meld into previous commit
f, fixup = like "squash", but discard this commit's log message
x, exec = run command (the rest of the line) using shell
d, drop = remove commit

These lines can be re-ordered; they are executed from top to bottom.

If you remove a line here THAT COMMIT WILL BE LOST.

However, if you remove everything, the rebase will be aborted.

I'm assuming I rebased and aborted too many times. 
Should I try this: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/squash_and_merge.html?

I added a screenshot of the webapp to Settings -> Social Preview

author: lcatherine
comment:
Actually that's correct. 

git rebase -i 

Will automatically show you the list of all the commits since head that have yet to be pushed.

(-i means interactive mode)

You can then change the keywords in front of them to squash everything except for the most recent commit, then change the commit message to something that encapsulates what is now in the new commit.

https://git-scm.com/docs/git-rebase#_interactive_mode

comment:
So I would say if the function is not going to be used by other handlers, then it's better to just make the code inline.  Since doPost is specifically handling user comments, it's okay to do the validation inside it directly and that way you can throw exception if validation fails.

If the function getUserComment is to be reused, then you should return an error or some form of exception (with details about the error) from within in and that can then be thrown as an exception in the doPost handler.

author: jonathanjlin

comment: nit: be consistent with whether to use spaces or tabs so that content in your repository looks consistent. At Google typically we only use spaces

author: jonathanjlin
comment: For all variables other than local variables, prefer to declare them as final so that readers (and future debuggers) won't have to look out for where this is mutated. This is a case of preferring immutability in general: as if you mark datas as final, the List interface includes methods for mutation. If you have time, you can try to incorporate third party libraries into your project and use ImmutableList (https://guava.dev/releases/23.0/api/docs/com/google/common/collect/ImmutableList.html) here, as that will communicate to readers that not only does datas always refer to the same list, but that list doesn't change

author: jonathanjlin

A clearer way of getting a random integer is by using a Random object:
Random random = new Random()
random.nextInt(datas.size())
