This shouldn't be an instance variable, otherwise you'll get different behavior on consecutive requests.

/data --> returns 10 comments
/data?max-comments=5 --> returns 5 comments
/data --> returns 5 comments, even though it should return the default number of comments

author: jayspringfield
comment: In Java (and only in Java), every class inherits from the Object class, which itself has a member function toString(), which returns a string representation of the object. It's best to use this whenever you need a String value. It doesn't especially matter right now, since we know this is a String object and for objects of the String class, toString() will just return the object and cast it to String for you. If you knew for sure it's always a String being returned, casting would be faster but it is less resilient to future code changes, and in user facing code like a webserver it's best to prefer reliability over speed (within reason).

author: mmallett
comment:
Can use Java Optional here

```java
return Optional.ofNullable(request.getParameter(name))).orElse(defaultValue);
```

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Optional.html

author: eldrickb
comment: Is this preferable to a conditional `?:` operator?

author: mmallett
comment:
Yes, Optional has more goodies to make this type of logic very simple and concise.

Even for this use case, it's compressed into one line instead of 2 lines or 2 calls to getParameter.

```java
String name = request.getParameter(name);
return name == null ? defaultValue : name;
```

Vs the optional

```java
return Optional.ofNullable(request.getParameter(name))).orElse(defaultValue);
```

But what's really nice about optional is it includes methods for calling another function, throwing an error, checking if the value is present, basically encapsulating all null checks into this class so you don't really need to check for null pointers

author: mmallett
comment:
> Why do both keys and IDs exist?

```
Each entity in a Datastore mode database has a key that uniquely identifies it. The key consists of the following components:

The namespace of the entity, which allows for multitenancy
The kind of the entity, which categorizes it for the purpose of queries
An identifier for the individual entity, which can be either
a key name string
an integer numeric ID
An optional ancestor path locating the entity within the database hierarchy
```
https://cloud.google.com/datastore/docs/concepts/entities#key

A more generic answer, not specific to DataStore:

In most databases, you have a **primary key** which uniquely identifies each entity in the table. This is usually an increasing `long int` or a UUID. So the ID is both an ID and a Key, it's the primary key.

But you don't always know the primary key, and have some information about the entity and want to find it by that information. You can create other keys that the table is indexed on to speed up queries. Say you need to query comments created by a specific user, you could create a key for the comment user in addition to the primary key for that entity.

author: mmallett
comment:
Since this is a closure, the scope is maintained, so you only have to run the query once and the element would be cached.

```javascript
const el = document.getElementById(id);
```

Though I'm curious about the comment, is document undefined? You could move your `script` to the foot of the `<body>` instead of in the `<head>`.

You could also attach event listener to the page ready event.

```
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', fn);
```

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9899372/pure-javascript-equivalent-of-jquerys-ready-how-to-call-a-function-when-t

author: mmallett
comment:
This file contains DOM utils, API calls, authentication, and business logic. The code could be easier to follow and maintain if you divide out the concerns into their own file, and only expose an API for an index or controller script to call.

This could get particularly messy in the future as they all share the same script level scope, and some sections of the code, such as login rely on variables from this scope. I personally like wrapping things in classes, but I don't think the style guide takes a stance on class vs closures.

ES6 classes are basically like syntax sugar that make writing closures easier, IMO

https://google.github.io/styleguide/jsguide.html#features-classes
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes

author: mariabajzek
comment:
In this case I would make your DatastoreService object a member of your DataServlet class (like you have with comments and gson) and then you can refer to it in doGet().

As far as I can tell, the construction of the DatastoreService doesn't depend on anything in the specific request and response, and it will be less expensive to just create it once and reuse it.

This is good to keep in mind in general when you have an object that might be slow or expensive to create.

author: mariabajzek
comment:
A note about Java: Casting can be somewhat risky. In this case, [getProperty()](https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/java/javadoc/com/google/appengine/api/datastore/PropertyContainer.html#getproperty) is only guaranteed to return an Object. In this specific case, you know that the "comment" property will be an Object that is a String but you can imagine in a more complex application you might not be able to guarantee that. Maybe it would return a more general Object that can't be cast to a String.

One thing you can do to be sure it's safe to cast is to use the instanceof operator. [This](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7313559/what-is-the-instanceof-operator-used-for-in-java) is a good explanation of that.

I know there is some controversy over the use of instanceof, but I'm not aware of a better way to handle that situation. Also, I think your code should be fine here, I just wanted to make you aware of this (and you can add instanceof if you want to practice it).

author: mariabajzek
comment:
This is an ok way to handle this. You might want to consider adding an "else" here to specifically handle the case where you can't cast the comment to a string. Some reasonable behaviors I can think of are:

1. Set comment to something like "This comment cannot be loaded." This way it will be clear to a user (or to you, for debugging) that there was an issue with loading and someone didn't just submit an empty comment.

1. You could treat it as a real error and throw an exception. In this case you probably don't need to do that since you probably still want to try to load the rest of the page, but this is an option in general.
